characters: SPLIT SCREEN, WITH PENNY IN HER OFFICE
RECORD BREEDING DEAL FOR SECRETARIAT NABS SIX MILLION
A NEWSPAPER--THE DENVER STAR--WITH THE HEADLINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PENNY CHENERY TWEEDY, 40’s, intelligent, elegant, beautif walks down the staircase of her precisely arranged home. Though it’s early morning, she’s perfectly dressed, every hair in place. She checks her watch and calls out--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Breakfast in ten minutes! She opens the front door and lifts the morning newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: NOVEMBER 12, 1969
dialogues.text: Nixon Vows End to War It’s now lying beside a plate at a perfectly set table; J TWEEDY (Penny's married name is Tweedy), mid-40's, sits d and tucks a napkin above the knot of his necktie to cover white shirt. Penny is finishing making his omelet. They a INT. PENNY’S KITCHEN, DENVER - DAY With the expertise of long practice she slides the omelet into Jack's plate, places orange slices beside it, and be mixing pancakes. Jack doesn’t look up from the paper.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Court today?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It’s Tuesday, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (calling out) Sarah! Kate! You have—-

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (entering) Six minutes. Page 2 of 113 SARAH is 18; she hurries in and sits on one side of Jack sister KATE, 16, bounces in too, both girls kissing their father and automatically taking their places, as Penny quickly divides a skillet of eggs and kisses the girls on their heads. Chris and John, younger boys, come in soon after and sit at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Penny, I have three shirts to pick up at the cleaners and two more to go, in the hamper.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I got them yesterday, I’11 take the others this afternoon. He takes a list from his pocket and amends it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then you could also go by the wine shop and pick up some Riesling, I've got a client coming in and that’s all he drinks.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Mom, more juice please. Penny grabs the juice from the fridge without breaking fl

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I need to pick up a gown.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A gown? For a prom?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: No, it’s a party.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And you want a gown? When you earn your own money you can buy gowns for every party.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sure we can find something reasonable. We'll look this weekend, Penny writes this on a list she has going on the refrigerator, next to “shirts” and “wine.”

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not Gewurtzraminer. Only Riesling, they’1l1 try to fool you. Page 3 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm singing in the Christmas pageant.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Christmas pageant? In June?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It's experimental.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That’s great, honey! What part?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: The War Protestor.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: We can get-- I’m sorry, the what? Just then the phone rings, surprising everybody this earl Penny has lifted a bowl of pancake batter; she shoves it under one arm, tucks the phone between her shoulder and e and continues to stir as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Tweedy residence... This is she...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: War protestor? In a Christmas pageant?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s cutting edge, Dad. Penny drops the bowl; it crashes to the floor and she rem very still; steadying herself, she says into the phone--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I1'11 be there this afternoon. Her family is staring, no one moving as Penny hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: My mother... For a moment they are all as still as she is. Then the girls, then Jack and the boys, move to Penny and hug her; we PUSH IN on Penny‘s eyes, knowing there is so much she do, and not knowing where to begin. Page 4 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks EXT. “THE MEADOW,” A VIRGINIA HORSE FARM - DAY It’s a cold bleak day, and Penny rides in the passenger s of the rental car as Jack drives their family toward the Penny grew up in--the main house of a horse breeding farm Penny has a handwritten list.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’ve called the schools. Sarah, I couldn’t reach your volleyball coach but I'll reach him sometime today. John, your teacher said you can make up the math test Monday.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’m gonna miss rehearsals. They said you'd lose your role if you miss rehearsals.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: War Protestors are inherently irresponsible. Tell them you were just getting into character.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You‘re not going to lose the role. I’1l speak to them this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to call the Johnsons and tell them we‘ll miss dinner tomorrow night. Penny adds to her list. Jack turns the car into a lane marked by a sign: MEADOWS STABLES. The lane leads past we choked rail fences, to a stately house that needs paint. dozen cars are parked outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny leads her family inside; old friends of her parents gathered in groups throughout the main rooms, there to pa their respects. MISS HAM, mid-60’s, with Old Virginia manners, moves immediately to greet her with a genteel hu

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Penny, Darlin’, I’m so so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Miss Ham. Jack, kids, you remember Miss Ham, Granddaddy’s secretary? Penny’s children nod politely; Jack has things on his min Page 5 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you. Could I find a phone, I need to make some calls.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Of course, please use my office. Jack hurries off without a word. Miss Ham’s eyes, full of wisdom and sympathy, drift back to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. For everything. Hollis said you found her... in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: She was making your father his sandwich, and just fell over. The doctor said she didn’t suffer. She looked peaceful, even there.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: How is Daddy? Daddy seems a childlike term for a grown woman to use abo her father, but it’s what Southerners say til their own d day. Miss Ham's eyes tell Penny the situation is grim.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: He keeps asking, Where is she? I’m not sure if he means your Mother, or you. Miss Ham looks down a long hallway, where none of the gue have gone. Penny turns to her daughters, and speaks quiet (The boys have already approached the food table.)

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go see your Granddaddy, and then I’ll bring you in. I know all this isn’t easy for you; it’s frightening, it’s a terrible time. But Grandma is with the angels. And today you become women.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Come on, Girls, let’s get you something to eat. As Miss Ham ushers the girls away, she glances back once to Penny. We FOLLOW PENNY, as she moves down the long hallway, line with pictures of racehorses, toward the door at the end. Page 6 of 113  As she walks, MEMORIES OF HORSERACING--wild, vibrant, colorful--bang into her spirit, colliding and contrasting with the somber gray of her life in general and this mome in particular. We see WHAT SHE SEES IN HER MEMORY: --A little girl--Penny, at 6--standing at the rail of a racetrack, beside her tall, handsome father--CHRISTOPHER CHENERY--in the prime of his life, as the crowd thunders around them... --A pack of racehorses rounding a turn and heading into t home stretch, hooves pounding, muscles rippling, colors flashing, the horses thundering toward the wire. Her father’s horse wins, and BULL HANCOCK {a friend we’1l com know) claps him on the back in celebration. Young Penny looks up at her Dad; he smiles down at her, a takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS CHENERY
dialogues.text: We let ’em run, Penny! We always let ’em run! And ADULT PENNY walks toward his office door. Pausing for the slightest moment to steel herself, she opens the door INT. CHRISTOPHER CHENERY’S OFFICE - DAY This is the office of a man who has achieved a great deal having started from the humblest beginnings. On the walls are pictures of Christopher Chenery with President Kenned another with President Johnson. In one photo Chris is cutting a ribbon at the dedication of a massive power station. But most of the shots are of him with horses. We PAN ACROSS the pictures to find Chris Chenery now: he’ dressed, his hair is combed; but he’s late 70’s now, and thinner, his mind drifting into dementia. As Penny enters

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: Helen. Where’s my sandwich? There is already a sandwich on the table beside him. Penn leans and kisses him tenderly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy. It’s Penny. She sits on the ottoman in front of him and takes his han in hers. He doesn’t respond, except to frown slightly, li a man who is troubled by a memory, no more than a hunch. Page 7 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen...? Penny struggles to say the words; when she does, it’s fir

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mother’s gone, Daddy. It’s Penny.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: No. No... Penny’s gone. She got married. Penny is doing everything she can to be strong, to see th situation clearly. But it’s hard to see clearly when tear are dripping from your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More people are gathered in small knots of mumbling mourn in the house’s expansive main room. Jack has returned fro his phone calls and is talking with HOLLIS CHENERY, 50, Penny’s brother. He’s a tall man, soft from a life of des work, sorting through investments.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: The farm won’t bring much. I'd rather be liquid and have the money in stocks. When this Vietnam thing ends I see a bull market. Penny spots him and moves up; they hug.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hollis.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: You just saw Father? She can only nod. Her eyes find her children, standing at the window and looking out at the horses in the fields an wishing they could be anyplace but here.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I hadn’t realized how quickly he was losing it. When I’d call, it would always be Mother on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes. We've got a lot to deal with. Page 8 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the Estate Tax is seventy percent?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Jack’s told me about the taxes, I meant——

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Seventy percent, Penny. If he dies before we can restructure assets into shelters, we could lose almost everything.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can help you with all of that.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I need to see to the children.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: {to Hollis) So how’s business in New York? As her husband and brother talk shop, Penny moves to her children at the window. She kneels and whispers to them--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’1l take you in to see Granddaddy. I just need a minute. The girls squeeze her waist, understanding, as women instinctively do, that grief means love. Penny looks outside; standing out by the paddock fence is EDDIE SWEAT, 33, black, the farm's horse-groom; he’s in h work clothes. At that moment CARL HATTON, 40’s, the horse trainer, comes up and begins to berate him because no training is going on; Eddie gestures sadly toward the hou Penny closes her eyes... When she opens them, she is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: »..and Penny is standing at the grave side between her fa and Jack, with their children next to him. Gathered aroun the grave are fifty friends and neighbors, as the family' PASTOR is praying over the grave. Page 9 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: »..and so we return to You the spirit of your faithful servant, Helen Chenery. Loving mother, devoted wife, who lived each moment to the fullest, cherishing the life she had with her beloved husband Christopher. As they lower her mother’s casket into the ground, Penny squeezes her father’s hand...and he squeezes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the mourners are making their way to their cars, Penny sees the groom, Eddie Sweat, and moves up to him. (Miss H is helping Chris Chenery to the car.)

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Eddie. Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Miss Penny. Your Mama was a fine woman. I feel real bad for Mister Chenery.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He always admired you. Said you were the best groom in the world. Eddie nods gratefully and steps away as BULL HANCOCK, now Moves up with his son SETH, 21.

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tweedy? Arthur Hancock. Your Daddy called me--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Bull. And so did everybody else, as I recall.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: And this is my son, Seth. She shakes hands with both of them.

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Your mother was a fine woman. It was a privilege knowing her. Your father and me... Well, even if he’s half the man he was, he’s still a better man than most. I know you’1l be making some changes; (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 10 of 113  10. BULL HANCOCK (cont'd) if you or your family have any questions, Miss Ham has my number. He starts away, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Your father’s eyes always lit up, whenever he talked about you. How smart you are. And how much you loved the horses. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE - DAY Christopher sits in his favorite chair, cblivious to the funeral crowd milling around the house. Penny moves to hi

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: How you doing, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER CHENERY
dialogues.text: Helen?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No, Daddy, it’s Penny. We came out from Denver to... to see you. Silence for a moment. He points at a photograph, showing and a horse and jockey in a winner’s circle.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The day Hill Prince won in Maryland.

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER CHENERY
dialogues.text: We let him run that day, didn’t we? Always let ’em run. Always let ‘em run. Penny gives her father a gentle kiss on the forehead. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - GREAT ROOM - NIGHT Hollis pours himself a drink; Penny’s staring out the win The funeral visitors have gone, it’s now just family.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Doctor says there may be some brief moments when he’s aware of things, but we shouldn’t expect much. Especially after this. He takes a drink; he needs it. Page 11 of 113  ll.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Practical thing would be to put him in a nursing home.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: This is home to him, he knows he’s here. As long as he does I think we should hire nurses and let him stay at home.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: The farm needs to go. I just checked the books, it’s been losing money for years. No reply. Hollis knows his younger sister can be stubborn

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Look, I know you loved this place, we all did, okay? But he made it work, he once made lots of things work. He’s not that man anymore, and we have to face facts. To run a racehorse business you need a certain touch. I’m a stockbroker and you're a housewife. He takes another drink, and Penny's eyes move from him to Jack and their children, visible through the door into th next room. Jack is on the phone, while the kids look thro old photo albums. Jack hangs up and moves in to join them

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ve moved up our flight to first thing tomorrow, we gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I need to stay a few days longer. Find the right nurse for Daddy, sort through Mother’s things.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But I just changed your ticket.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: This place is a mess. And somebody needs to make sure Daddy is all right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's got Miss Ham, she’s like family. Page 12 of 113  12.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Maybe I need to be here. For me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What about the kids?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: They’11 be all right, Sarah can do with a little responsibility. It‘ll only be a few days.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: We need to file right away to get his power of attorney. Miss Ham says he tried to sell four of his best horses last month, for half of what they're worth. Mom had to step in and stop him. Now...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I suppose someone will have to clean up for the liquidation.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It‘ll only be a few days. I promise. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” — GUEST BEDROOM - NIGHT Penny can’t sleep. Jack's next to her, no such problems. She pushes back the covers and drifts out of bed... INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE — MOMENTS LATER Penny approaches the wall of photographs and trophies. Th office is dark, lit only by the Virginia moonlight. She touches the ball of yarn with the half-finished scarf her mother had been knitting. It’s in a checkerboard pattern, blue and white. On the table beside the chair is a framed photograph; Pen lifts it and sees: a photo of Chris and Penny {she looks or so), standing next to a majestic horse, father and daughter smiling broadly. EXT. “THE MEADOW" -— DAWN .»--and we see the farm in its natural beauty, a lazy mis hanging tight to the rolling fields where horses graze. Page 13 of 113  13. EXT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” — SAME Penny stands beside the car that contains Jack and their children; she’s smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: This’1l be fun for you! Sarah makes great pancakes!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: They’re toxic! We won’t survive! Their laughter tells Penny the children will be fine. Jac is different, all business as he starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Make sure Hollis has that Power of Attorney order. The estate’s vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’11 stay on him. No kiss, no smile from Jack. Penny pats the car, then wav goodbye and smiles cheerfully as the car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (calling back) Give Granddaddy a hug for us when he wakes up!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I will! Be good! I love youl As the car disappears onto the main road, Penny is left i guiet isolation. It’s as if the farm has become a cemeter and the grazing horses markers of the graves of what once thriving, and alive. INT. "THE MEADOW” - MAIN BARN - MOMENTS LATER A barn for race horses and brood mares is a beautiful pla especially when the sun has just lit the damp morning air Penny appears in the broad doorway and makes her way alon the long row of horse stalls, reacquainting herself with place and a life she’d largely forgotten. She stops at a stall that holds a beautiful mare, whose stall plate tell her is SomethingRoyal.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hey girl... You-- you’re expecting! Page 14 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks 14. Penny scratches the mare’s nose, then drifts to the end o the barn, finds a bale of hay, and she sits. There it hit her: the loss of her mother, the decline of her father, t distance in her marriage, the sense that somehow, somewhe she’s made a wrong turn. She hears a footstep and looks up quickly; Miss Ham has entered the barn holding two cups of steaming coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Miss Ham! Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Thought you'd like a pick-me-up. Two sugars and a cream?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: How’d you know?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: It's how your Daddy likes it. You doin’ all right, Honey?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes. No. I’11 be all right.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: I have something else for you. When the doctor sent back her effects, I brought them in to your father. He took this out and handed it to me. She hands Penny a small decorative pin of a horse and joc

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mother’s good luck pin. So he wanted you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: No. He didn’t believe it was me he was giving it to.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He thought you were Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: He thought I was you. All he said was, “Penny.” {beat) I’1l see you back at the house. Page 15 of 113  15. Miss Ham is starting away, to leave her in solitude, when DOWN THE BREEZEWAY: a commotion as the farm’s trainer, Ca Hatton, yells to Eddie Sweat, the groom, who has led up a horse to saddle it for morning exercise.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: Eddie! Who the hell told you to bring this one out?!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, I figured--

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: --you figure nothing! Put him back and bring out that yearling in 18!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mister Hatton. Hatton sees Miss Ham and doesn’t mind a bit that she’s he his tirade; then he notices Penny.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I'm Penny Tweedy. Penny Chenery.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. I’m sorry about your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother.... I got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (standing) Excuse me; Eddie, hold off for a minute on that yearling in 18. Could I speak with you, Mr. Hatton? In private?

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: About what? Penny looks at Miss Ham and Eddie, who quickly leave.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: I know you and your brother aren‘t horse people, Missy, and you’ve had a loss and all, but you don’t come into a barn and interrupt a trainer’s work. Not if you want to keep him. Page 16 of 113  16.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I understand. I just wanted to ask you about the sale of those brood mares that my mother stopped a few weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: They were worth twice what we were going to sell them for. I couldn’t sleep last night, so I checked the books, and made some calls this morning to be sure.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: I don’t own the horses, your father has to sell ‘em!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: But as trainer you’d know their worth, and that they were about to be sold. What I was wondering is why it had to be my Mother who stopped the sale, and not you. OUTSIDE THE BARN, EAVESDROPPING, are Miss Ham and Eddie, hanging on every word. INSIDE THE BARN, Hatton is looking at Penny as he might w a copperhead he just walked up on.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: The old man, your father. Ask him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I'm asking you. My father’s been sick a long time, and you’ve been paid to look out for his interests.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: I dol Just cause this place is going downhill, it ain’t my fault!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The sale was going to be to Old Dominion Farms. I learned this morning that the owners of Old Dominion were already talking about selling our horses at twice the price they were paying us. And you train for them too, don’t you? Page 17 of 113  17.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: ...Sometimes. So what?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So if you arranged a deal that gave them four race horses for half their market value, and they paid you back with an extra share of everything they made, that wouldn’t just be disloyal. It would be conspiracy to commit a felony. OUTSIDE, Miss Ham and Eddie are wide-eyed. INSIDE...

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are?! Accusing me!?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: My husband’s a lawyer and my father’s Christopher Chenery. And I'm not Missy anything. Get your things and get off my farm.

dialogues.speaker: CARL HATTON
dialogues.text: I have a contract! I/‘11 sue you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: If I ever even hear your name again I’1l see you go to prison. OUTSIDE, Miss Ham and Eddie are going crazy in silent jubilation! Carl Hatton stalks by them, beet red, beaten. Miss Ham and Eddie are stunned; as Penny appears they try look casual. Penny seems distant, as if surprised at what she just did. But she’s focused too, acting on instinct.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Miss Ham, I'd better look at the farm’s business calendar and anything else you think I need to see. Eddie, Mr. Hatton won't be training our horses anymore, so please keep them healthy til we figure out what to do.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. Penny walks to the house. Page 18 of 113  18. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE -— DAY Penny sits at her father’s desk, looking out the window. Miss Ham places a stack of books in front of her. Eddie appears, hat in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Miz Chenery?...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m a good groom, ma’am-—

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The best, I hear.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m good. I know the horses, I can feel ‘em through the brush the way a jockey feels ‘em through the reins. But I’m not a trainer. I don’t know how hard to run ‘em or how long to rest ’em. Mr. Hatton, he’s been saying all these horses would be sold. And if you want to fetch a good price they need to be fit to run. You need a real trainer.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Eddie. Eddie leaves; Penny looks at Miss Ham.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Where does Bull Hancock eat lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny’s high heels click-clack up the marble steps toward reception desk, where a stodgy RECEPTIONIST is on the pho

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Arlington Club, may I help you? ».-Yes sir, I’11 put you through. (to Penny) How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, I was told Bull Hanceck might be here. Page 19 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks 19.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Could be. Would you like to leave a message for him?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I'd like to see him, please.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You’re not from around here, are you, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: This is a gentlemen’s club. Would you like to leave a message? Penny stares at the woman, who looks back at her like a q at a peasant. Then, suddenly, Penny walks past her. INT. ARLINGTON CLUB -— MAIN DINING ROOM — CONTINUOUS Penny walks purposefully, looking for Bull; some of the o men recognize her and begin to whisper; it’s a tight circ and they’ve already heard about Carl Hatton. Bull sees Pe and stands to welcome her, as the Receptionist catches up

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, she just-——

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Would you please tell Mr. Hancock that Penny Tweedy would like a word with him? Bull waves the receptionist away and pulls out a chair fo Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Forgive me for disturbing you.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: On the contrary, it’s my pleasure. A WAITER pours a tumbler of the best bourbon money can bu

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I just fired Carl Hatton.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: Do tell. So does that mean you're selling the horses, or keepin’ ’em? Page 20 of 113  20.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The farm's in bad shape, like my father is. But I’m not gonna sell it for less than it’s worth.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: A horse farm needs a strong hand on the reins. The hand that threw Carl Hatton out the door looks pretty strong to me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: My life’s back in Denver. I need a good trainer, just to get things stabilized.

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: (writing on his napkin) Talk to Lucien Laurin. He’s up in New York right now. French Canadian trainer. Fat white guy, dresses like Superfly. He's sort of retired.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What do you mean he’s sort of retired? INT. NEW YORK RACING PARK — BETTING WINDOW - DAY LUCIEN LAURIN, 50’s, with a taste for garish clothes and especially for fedora hats, stands at a pay phone beside betting windows and calls to the teller...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Three on the top with 1, 4, 6 and 8 on the bottom. I'’11 take the same on a trifecta three and one. As the teller hands him the tickets, Lucien says into the phone--

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Okay, what?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Laurin, if you could just hear me out for a few minutes-—- Page 21 of 113  The 21.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tweedy, I’m flattered Bull told ya to call, but I’m tired of baby-sitting half-ton animals that are stubborn or stupid. Or both.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I understand that, sir, but I’m in a bit of a tight spot. Could you try it for a few months to see how things go?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Trainers go where they can find a good horse, not to pick up a few months work.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: We've got plenty of good horses.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: No you don’t. You’ve got one or two that might be worth the time. And please don’t take this wrong, but you’re a little short on people who know what they're doing.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Lady, you're not hearing me. A trainer gets rich off commissions-- 10 percent off winners, 10 on sales. To get a top trainer you need a top horse. Go back to Bull and see if he's got any other ideas.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: But Mr. Laurin-- two of my mares are pregnant by Bold Ruler and he’s the best stallion in the whole-- "Call To Post” sounds behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, I gotta go. He hangs up. And Penny, in her father’s office, looks up see Hollis storming in, wearing golf clothes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: You fired our trainer?! Page 22 of 113  22.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hollis. You didn’t fly home?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I stayed for a meeting and it’s a good thing I did! We need a trainer in place! How could you fire him?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He was worse than incompetent. He was dishonest. He had to go. Hollis tries to rub away a headache--and reality. Penny is lectured And he’s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As horse

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I don't know any more about horses than you do! But I know we need a trainer to keep the horses fit enough to unload them.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m working on it, Hollis. I’ve got a line on one, recommended by Bull Hancock.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Well... at least Bull Hancock knows what he’s doing and our father trusted him. The estate tax will kill us, Penny-- do you realize that? When Dad dies, we're out of time and it’s a fire sale. silent, trying not to show her anger in being on what she already knows.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Look, I know this is a strain for you, being away from home. Just find a nurse for Dad and you can get back to Jack and the kids. I gotta go. eff again, leaving Penny with the whole mess.

dialogues.speaker: YORK RACING PARK
dialogues.text: race past the finish line, Lucien watches in defeat and tears up the last of his worthless betting tickets fo the day. He’s at bottom, with nowhere to go. Page 23 of 113  23. EXT. NEW YORK RACING PARK — PARKING LOT — DAY Lucien owns an old Cadillac, from the days when he traine winners. He opens the trunk, and finds a stack of breedin books there; he finds a book and opens it to BOLD RULER. tracks down to two entries, Hasty Matelda and SomethingRo mares at The Meadows, owner: Christopher Chenery. INT. THE MEADOW - CHRIS CHENERY’S BEDROOM -— NIGHT Penny moves to the door and watches her father sleeping, peacefully. INT. THE MEADOW - PENNY’S ROOM - NIGHT She’s leafing through the mail when a formal envelope cat her eye; it bears the return address of Ogden Phipps. She pulls it cut and looks at it for a beat. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE -— NIGHT Penny sets down three of her father’s handwritten journal The top one is titled: Hasty Matelda. She opens it, and t second one: SomethingRoyal. Then she opens the third book Bold Ruler, and places them so that she can compare all t together. And she begins to study, absorbing everything. CLOSE on a steaming CUP OF COFFEE. Penny draws a line fro one generation to the next, now scribbling notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is on the phone with Penny--SPLIT SCREEN AT THE MEAD OFFICE. In Denver, Chris and John are cleaning the plates from the dinner table; the house is noisy and chaotic; Pe in her quiet office, savors the distant sounds of home.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So how’s Kate’s play?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: {covering receiver) Kate! Want to talk with your Mom?

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m on the other line with Trent!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She’s on the other line with somebody. Page 24 of 113  24.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Probably Trent.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who’s Trent?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Her new boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: She has a boyfriend? When are you coming back?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Soon. I just want to tell you about the coin toss! The kids are playing behind him, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What?! Kids, quiet! Coin toss?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Stallions cost more than mares, they’re more glamorous, but since a great horse comes from the mare as much as the stallion, Daddy invested in mares. That's the first smart thing he does. The second is, he makes a deal with Ogden Phipps.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Phipps. Richest man in America?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Instead of paying a stud fee, Daddy makes a deal to breed Phipps’ best stallion to our best two mares. When the mares are near term they flip a coin to choose who gets which foal. The coin flip’s in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So what? I don’t have any idea which horse to choose. For only a moment it registers with Penny that Jack assum she wants him to make a decision, rather than support her Page 25 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve been into the breeding books. The sire, Bold Ruler, was fast but couldn’t last over distances. The dams are Hasty Matelda and SomethingRoyal. Hasty Matelda had lots of speed, so she’s the obvious choice. But SomethingRoyal’s grandsire was Princequillo. He had great stamina and--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Penny? Penny!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: --What?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sire and dam and Sam-I-Am? What is this? He's laughing at her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Come on. We need you. Your children need you. Come home. There is a long, deflating silence.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Right after the coin toss. She hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING the Arlington Club, reeking of wealth.

The club is crowded with genteel horsemen and club member OGDEN PHIPPS, (70), the richest man in this or any other room, takes a glass of champagne, then waits for Penny to take one, served her by the stodgy receptionist. fellow multi-millionaires listen in as...

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Please don’t take offense to this, Mrs. Tweedy, but your father never won our coin tosses and I do hope you’ve inherited his luck. Page 26 of 113 Phipps’  26

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: If I were in your shoes, Mister Phipps, I’d hope the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: The President of the Racing League makes the toss. It’ll be in five minutes. He steps away, leaving Penny alone. Bull Hancock sees her and moves over. He clicks his glass to hers.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: Good luck. Hollis arrives and moves to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hollis... Back from New York?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: This is a big call, the foal could be worth a great deal. I checked with some of Phipps’s people, they think he wants Hasty Matelda’s foal. So that’s who we'll choose.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I think that’s wrong, Hollis. SomethingRoyal‘s colt could have an unusual mix of speed and stamina.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous. You think you know more than Ogden Phipps’ people?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m just saying I’ve studied the breeding books. Have you?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: What would you do, Mr. Hancock?

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: I’d mind my own business.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I’m asking you as my father’s best friend for your best opinion.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: The conventional wisdom is Hasty Matelda. Page 27 of 113  27.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: (calling over) We're ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the SHINY COIN in Bull’s big hand. Penny and Ogd stand across from each other, surrounded by rich onlooker

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Mister Phipps has the call. Winner has the choice between the offspring of Mr. Chenery’s mares Hasty Matelda or SomethingRoyal. Are we in agreement? Phipps and Penny nod. Bull tosses the coin.

dialogues.speaker: BULL HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Call it in the air!

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Heads! »..and it hits the floor and settles on: HEADS. Penny’s e close in disappointment. Phipps smiles, supremely confide

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: I’1l go with Hasty Matelda. Phipps turns toward his cadre of supporters and they lift their glasses to him.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Miz Chenery, you have your father’s luck. Please give him my best. Phipps moves to celebrate with his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Well, that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: But... I got what I wanted!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: You got what nobody else wanted. Time to go home. Hollis leaves.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: Can I give you a lift home? Page 28 of 113  28.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I brought my car.

dialogues.speaker: BULL
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean to take sides.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You didn’t, you told the truth. Bull moves to congratulate Phipps. Penny, alone again, tu and wanders toward the door, walking slowly, trying to co to terms with the fact that she felt so sure of something everyone else saw another way. AT THE DOOR Penny collides with Lucien Laurin, rushing in

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: ‘Scuse me! ...You Miz Chenery?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Laurin?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, how’d you know? His clothes are strikingly tasteless.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lucky guess.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: My plane was late, who won the toss?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Phipps. He took Hasty Matelda.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He did? Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That surprise you?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: No. But I would’a taken SomethingRoyal. And in that moment, their partnership is born.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: When she drops her colt, call me. Page 29 of 113  Iturned my screenplay into a MPS and I's WANING DOWEY] = Tuar's THE Facr, sncK!
INT. TWEEDY HOME, DENVER — DAY Penny is cleaning up in the kitchen after dinner when the phone rings. Jack, reading in the adjacent den, answers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Tweedy Residence. EDDIE’S VOICE Miz Chenery there?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Penny. It’s for Miz Chenery. She moves in and takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: {into phone) This is Penny.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The colt’s on its way. Penny looks up at Jack. INT. "THE MEADOW” — MAIN BARN — NIGHT SomethingRoyal is on her side, ready to deliver. Eddie is his knees beside the mare. As is Lucien. And Penny.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Water broke just past midnight. Any minute now. Everyone’s tense. Penny rubs a hand along the mare’s neck

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Doin’ fine, girl. Doin’ fine.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okay, here we go. Mr. Laurin, make sure-—

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: --I’ve got it. Penny soothes SomethingRoyal the whole time...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’ve done this four times, girl.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: She's done it fourteen. Page 30 of 113  30. They wait, and in a rush...the COLT tumbles onto the grou Eddie and Lucien are right there to help him. The colt is RED, with THREE WHITE SOCKS and a STAGGERED BLAZE on his face. Eddie laughs and shakes his head. The colt staggers to its feet.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You ever see that before?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Colt stand up that fast.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Mon dieu...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What? What?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That boy’s a whopper. They stare at the COLT, a miracle of birth, and life... Our music rises (we will have a grand SECRETARIAT theme) A MONTAGE of Penny's life and the colt’s growth, intertwi --The colt in a dew-soaked field, suckling from SomethingRoyal, as Penny watches... --Penny at home in Denver, caring for her own children, feeding them, helping them with homework, silently cringi as Jack ridicules Kate’s hippie attire; Penny soothes Kat braiding her hair and weaving in a flower; Kate loves it. --Penny, back in Virginia, touches the growing mane of th growing colt, and he surprises Penny and Eddie by nuzzlin his head against Penny’s chest. She smiles, moved... --Penny in an airplane seat, going through ledgers as she flies home; DISSOLVE THROUGH to Penny at home, doing dish picking up her children’s clothes, laughing with them as play after dinner and the girls talk on the phone; Penny doing laundry... then sitting at her desk late into the n in her office at home. The MONTAGE ENDS as Jack walks in, rumpled and sleepless in his pajamas; Penny looks up from ledgers and glances at the clock: it’s past midnight. Page 31 of 113  31.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m almost done.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How long do you think you can live two lives at once?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The colts are looking good and the new trainer's working hard; we've cut expenses; we're breaking even. She feels good about this; Jack doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought the point was to sell the farm, not to break even. She glances at a picture on the desk: she and Jack, young lovers in college, happy, optimistic. Beside it is a pict of the growing red colt.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: When I went off to college, I felt like... that colt. Full of promise and adventure. Like I could make something work. Now I want to see him run. I just want to see him run. Jack sighs, and without another word he leaves her. Now Penny feels no hurry to get to bed. What neither she nor Jack knows is that DOWN THE HALLWAY, Kate has been watching and hearing everything. Kate close the door to her room... switches on the light of her own desk, and starts doing her homework. Penny, alone at her desk, looks at the picture of the red colt. Rising in the background: the sound of THUNDERING

dialogues.speaker: HOOVES... WE SMASH INTO
dialogues.text: EXT. THE MEADOW FARMS - TRAINING TRACK — DAY CLOSE on the pounding chestnut legs of the same colt, now years old. We move up the sprinting animal...and reveal what’s happened over the past couple of years with SomethingRoyal‘s baby boy. The BRILLIANT COPPERY COLT rolls straight toward us, righ down the backstretch of The Meadow’s old training track. Page 32 of 113  32. Penny, Miss Ham and Lucien--wearing a new eyesore of a ha watch from the rail as he plows by.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He’‘s eleven hundred pounds of baby fat, that’s what I think. Lazy, eats too much, doesn’t have a clue how to run. Any other questions?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: I have one. How much did you spend on that hat? The colt and rider (JIMMY GAFFNEY, a lanky, tough exercis rider in his early 30’s) ride up toward the trio.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: How’s he look, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY GAFFNEY
dialogues.text: He’s just a big ol’ kid havin’ fun out there. He’ll figure it out. {pats the colt) Ain’t that right, Red? The horse tosses his head. Penny rubs his nose, then watc him with affection as Jimmy walks him away.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Red. I wish we could race him under that name.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: The Jockey Club insists on unique names; I keep sending ’em and they keep rejecting ‘em. I’ve tried Something Special, Royal Line, Deo Volente...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Deo Volente? “God Willing"?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. And God may have been willing but the Jockey Club wasn't. I’1l keep going through the dictionary til something clears.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: There’s a race in two weeks up at Aqueduct. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 33 of 113  33. LUCIEN (cont'd) Sets up nice for his first time out...not that I‘m expecting much.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Let’s enter him then. He jots down a note, before jabbing Miss Ham one last tim

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Deo Volente.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Mon dieu. EXT. ”’THE MEADOW” - MAIN BARN — DAY Eddie Sweat is washing down the big horse. Penny walks up

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hey Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Ma‘ am. She gives the big horse a rub on his nose. He likes it.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lucien says he couldn't beat a fat man running down a hill.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, he should know, ma’am. Penny smiles; then Eddie takes the chance to share someth he’s seen, with a woman he admires.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He could be a fine one. Right now he’s all sleep and eat. But he’s got fire inside him. And you see those ears? There’s plenty in between ‘em. Red turns his head and snorts, as if to say, “darn right.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m heading home for a few days. Do me a favor though before I go? EXT. MAIN HOUSE AT "THE MEADOW” — DAY Eddie and Penny hold Red’s twin leads as they walk him up Page 34 of 113  34. Christopher Chenery, sitting in a chair outside of the ma house; an impeccable nurse is just tucking a flannel blan over his legs as Penny guides the big horse closer...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hey Daddy, brought you some company. The dull expression on Christopher Chenery’s face flicker just a bit. He may not remember much, but he knows a good looking horse when he sees one. He struggles to stand, and succeeds. Penny takes his hand he uses the other to reach for the horse and pet his nose And then Penny calmly explains, hoping that a part of him will hear...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He’‘s the Bold Ruler colt, Daddy. From SomethingRoyal. We call him Big Red. He’s a nice one, isn’t he? A touch of a smile on Christopher’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING of Penny’s home in Denver. It’s early summer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the DENVER POST NEWSPAPER that Jack’s reading at dining room table. HEADLINE: “Hanoi and Vietcong Ask Rene of Paris Talks” He folds it up as Penny brings dinner in, a COCKTAIL alre near his table-setting. The entire family is there.

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s good you’re home. Your daughters have something they want to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oh? What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Kate and I are thinking of going to South America. Just for a couple of months. Page 35 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South America. What for?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: To teach English. It’s part of a peace mission.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS
dialogues.text: A mission to protest the war is what they mean.

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s not why we’re going. Alright? Although, if an opportunity did present itself...

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: {to Penny) See? This is what you're missing. Our teenage daughters growing up to become hippies. He reaches for his cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hippies are free spirits.

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Hippies are walking garbage--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: ».-alright, let’s just enjoy our dinner, okay? Quiet for a beat. Penny asks the girls...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: When do you need to let them know?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: There's a meeting for parents on the fifth, the day after my new play.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Both of you can make it, right?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The new colt runs his first race on the fourth. It’s in New York. I’1l catch the first flight back. Page 36 of 113 35  36. Jack is silent, disapproving. He barely shows it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: By the way, Miss Ham called. Something about a name for the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small BAND blasts out a JOHN PHILIP SOUSA tune. TITLE:

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT P-A ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...rounding out the field for the second race...Knightly Dawn and Secretariat. Five and a half furlongs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the band can still be heard as Lucien (weari red, white and blue plaid HAT), Penny, Miss Ham and a you jockey, PAUL FELICIANO, 18, talk before the race. The big red horse (not wearing any head-gear) stands in t midst; nervous, fidgety. Eddie works to keep him calm whi Lucien spills all his worry onto the jockey.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Alright, it’s a short race, so watch for the number six, he’s got the speed. Number three’1ll hold back, but five and eight might do the same. And keep an eye on number one, he might be the best horse in the field.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Are there any horses he doesn’t have to worry about?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Did I say number two?

dialogues.speaker: FELICIANO
dialogues.text: We're number two.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Right. (beat) Watch out for number two. Page 37 of 113  37. A distant trumpet blasts out the call to post. The jockey nods to Penny and mounts Secretariat. As he’s led away--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Our jockey’s mighty young.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He’s not my first choice, but he’s good, he’1l do. Miss Ham stares at Lucien for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: What? You don’t like my hat? (lecks to Penny) Do you like my hat? For a moment, Penny is a deer in headlights, desperate no embarrass Lucien, she can’t look away from the hat and ca escape the moment; she turns red, then bursts out laughin

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Lucien, I-- But I do like the hat, I actually... (choking laughter) I actually DO, I- Laughing, she hugs Lucien; then she turns reflective.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Nothing, it’s just that... That's the first time I’ve laughed, really laughed, since... since I don’t remember when. Penny walks toward the grandstands. Lucien watches her go

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: She scares me. Miss Ham gives him a steely look.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Good. She heads off to join Penny. Lucien, baffled, follows. EXT. AQUEDUCT RACE TRACK —- RAIL ON THE STRETCH - DAY A young sportswriter, BILL NACK (early 30's), studies the racing form as he leans against the rail. Page 38 of 113  38. ANDY BEYER {late 20’s, racing analysis whiz kid from New York) settles in on the rail next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: So what are you thinkin’, Nack?

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: You’re the best handicapper I know, Andy. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Lotta horses that haven’t run a race yet. I’m curious about this Bold Ruler colt--Secretariat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny, Lucien and Miss Ham stand by the rail to watch as. AT THE STARTING GATE, the last horse is loaded in. The yo jockey, Feliciano, tries to calm the big horse.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIANO
dialogues.text: Settle down, boy... All around: the GATE CREW MEMBERS are shouting...

dialogues.speaker: GATE CREW
dialogues.text: Hold still! Everybody set? ».-Alright, we're good! We play the DETAILS and the building tension of the momen the Big Red horse’s twitching muscles, his wild eyes, his hooves, flaring nostrils... .»..And PENNY, hands on the railing in front of her, the equivalent of the horse; at that moment utterly alone. The starting gates burst open, the bell screams: AND IN THE VERY FIRST SECOND, SECRETARIAT’S MAIDEN RACE G TO HELL IN A HANDBASKET. QUEBEC, the horse just to the right of Secretariat, emerg from the gate - and in a panic - veers directly into Big Red’s shoulder... .--knocking him off balance and straight into the horse t his left. Almost dropping him to the ground. PENNY looks as if someone drove an icepick into her spine Page 39 of 113  39. Feliciano jerks back on Secretariat, pulling him out of harm’s way...and into last place as they roll past Penny, Miss Ham and Lucien (growing angry already) on the rail. The horses settle into a rhythm as they approach the turn all except for Secretariat... .».-who turns too sharply and nudges a gray roan named RO just to his left...

dialogues.speaker: ROVE JOCKEY
dialogues.text: Back him off, kid! Feliciano eases Red to the right, but he’s reacting too m to every command; like a car that’s over-steering.

dialogues.speaker: FELICIANO
dialogues.text: Eassssy boy. ON THE RAIL: Penny, Lucien and Miss Ham watch... Nack and Beyer do the same.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Horse is all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses head into the stretch...and suddenly Secretari finds himself jammed in on the rail with nothing but hors all around him. Nowhere to run. A tight opening emerges directly on the rail and Felician chirps to his horse... .»..and Red instantly begins to pick up speed. He knocks one horse, then another, and another... But the big horse is too far back. Secretariat hits the finish line. Fourth.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT P-A ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Results from the second race, still unofficial: Herbull, finishing first, followed by Master Achiever, Fleet N’Royal, and Secretariat. Lucien angrily thumps the rail with his folded-up form an storms away. Penny stands alone at the rail, deflated. Page 40 of 113  40. EXT. AQUEDUCT RACE TRACK - DISMOUNT AREA — MOMENTS LATER Feliciano hops off Secretariat, handing the horse to Eddi A hopping-mad Lucien approaches, crumpling up a PIECE OF PAPER and tossing it to the ground as he does so. Penny’s right with him, while Miss Ham is a couple of steps behin

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: (cussing in French, and then:) You sure as hell messed that up!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIANO
dialogues.text: He got hit coming right out--

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Don’t even try kid, you’re off him!

dialogues.speaker: FELICIANO
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I said you’re done with him! Penny tries to step in...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lucien, stop. We need to talk about this...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Stay out of this! This is none of your business!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Go on, Paul. .»--and Feliciano walks away. Lucien, so pissed he forget for a second what language he’s speaking (a recurring pro for him), glares in Feliciano’s direction...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: ».-l'enfant ne savait pas ce qu'il faisait, le cheval n'aurait jamais dai perdre...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: That horse should never have lost that race! .--and he storms off. Eddie gently pulls Red away as Penn angry as well, stares after Lucien. Page 41 of 113  4l. Miss Ham approaches with the PIECE OF PAPER Lucien had to on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Well this explains a couple things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucien leans against the stall, running the race through mind. Penny walks up and hands him the losing ticket.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lot of money to bet on a fat, lazy horse. Must see something in him. (beat) Was it really Paul’s fault?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Probably not. (beat) This horse needs a jock with a lot more experience though. I want to go with Ronnie Turcotte. I would’ve put him up today, but he had another ride.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I want to meet with him, when I’m back in a couple weeks. But call him now, let’s make the change. One more thing. I’m still new to all this...and you know a lot more about it than I do. But don’t ever say this is none of my business. Every bit of this is my business. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. I’11 call him tomorrow. Miss Ham comes up.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: I just called to confirm your flight out. They’ve cancelled it due to weather. Penny winces; Kate’s play is tonight. Page 42 of 113  42. INT. JOCKEY’S ROOM - NEW YORK RACE TRACK -— DAY RONNIE TURCOTTE, 30ish, a tough-as-nails Canadian jockey, prepping for his next race, like a football player readyi for kickoff. A JOCKEY’S ATTENDANT answers a ringing phone JOCKEY’S ATTENDANT Yeah. Hang on. (yells to...) Turcotte! You got a call from Lucien Laurin!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Tell him my race is in ten minutes, I’11 call him back! ».-he grabs his helmet and whip... EXT. NEW YORK RACE TRACK — DAY .»..and he’s on top of a horse named OVERPROOF as the tig packed field heads down the backstretch. Everything is a more drab, non-descript: Turcotte’s clothing, the horse’s silks, etc. And we get a first-hand look - much as we did in Red's ra at Aqueduct - of the hand-to-hand combat that exists in t trenches of thoroughbred horse-racing. Banging. Jostling. Dirt everywhere. Turcotte reaches up with his hand and quickly flips up one of the FIVE SETS OF GOGGLE LENSES th protect his eyes from the dirt. He still can’t see much. The horses enter the homestretch, Overproof boxed in on t rail. Turcotte gives him the whip... Overproof responds, surging forward, eyes wide, nostrils flared... Then it happens in an instant. Overproof lurches to his right and collapses, slamming Ronnie to the ground with h And a heartbeat later every horse that was behind them is thundering by, one of them stepping on Turcotte. A FEW MINUTES LATER, track medics are loading Turcotte in an ambulance. He’s badly banged up. A couple of jockeys a the attendant are there to see if Turcotte’s still alive.

dialogues.speaker: TURCOTTE
dialogues.text: My horse?...

dialogues.speaker: JOCKEY ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Vet said his heart burst. Dead before he hit the ground. Page 43 of 113  43.

dialogues.speaker: TURCOTTE
dialogues.text: (beat) Tell Lucien I can ride in a week. INT. PENNY’S HOTEL ROOM —- NIGHT She‘s by herself, a room-service dinner barely touched be her. She dials a number... INTERCUT WITH A RINGING PAY PHONE, inside A High School auditorium in Denver. Student-made posters announce: “Pea On Earth? A Counter-Culture Pageant.” The phone rings onl once before young Chris Tweedy picks it up and answers——

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Is she on?

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS TWEEDY
dialogues.text: You just made it! He stretches the phone toward the auditorium entrance, wh Sarah and John are holding the decors open; Kate is on st dressed as a Vietamese soldier, singing--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Silent night... Holy Night... She’s singing at the top of her lungs, projecting to the phone, as her classmates, dressed as airplanes, hurl plas bombs at her. Penny listens from far away, rapt, both laughing and cryi at the same time. Chris whispers to her, into the receive

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Dad says it’s Commie Crap!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It's art, Honey. It’s art. And as Penny, alone in her hotel room, listens to her daughter singing, so far away, a tear slides down her che

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quiet, reserved hotel cafe. Penny sips from a cup of coffee as she looks across the table toward Turcotte, sti banged up, ribs wrapped, hand bandaged. Page 44 of 113  44.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lucien and I were hoping you might be ready for our next race, but--

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I'll be ready, why wouldn't I be? Penny likes this answer.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I talked to a few owners. They say you're one of the best, got a great touch, great with young horses. They also say you’1ll put a horse into traffic, get him caught where he can’t run. Or drive him too hard.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Lucien dit c’vrais. Lucien told the truth.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What’d he say?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: That you're hard as nails. Miz Chenery, I risk my life every time I climb on a horse. I’m not afraid, neither are they; I want to win just like they do. My last horse wanted to win so much his heart burst. It’s who they are. It's who I am. You want somebody else, get somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t want somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The splendor of Saratoga in upstate New York. The old sea are filled with OWNERS AND PATRONS whose families have be there for generations. We SUPERIMPOSE:

dialogues.speaker: SARATOGA, JULY, 1972
dialogues.text: Page 45 of 113  45. EXT. SARATOGA — DAY Penny and Miss Ham arrive in the owners’ area of the grandstand, and find themselves next to a TRIO OF OWNERS, former frat boys drunk since college twenty years ago. Pe exhales, nervous. The nearest of the owners says, too loudly..

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: So which of you ladies owns Secretary? His buddies laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: His name's Secretariat. And he's gonna make your horse take dictation.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: You don’t know which horses we own!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter. He’s gonna beat ‘em all. Lucien enters and stands next to Miss Ham, so tense he ca barely breathe. She looks at his clothes, mortified. EXT. SARATOGA -— TRACK -— DAY The starting gates tremble in anticipation; the bell RING and Secretariat, now wearing blinkers, blasts out... The Saratoga crowd - the bleachers packed - cheers in uni as the horses blister down the track. But Big Red settles toward the back of the pack once more PENNY, MISS HAM AND LUCIEN watch from the stands, already losing hope. They watch the horses moving into the back stretch.

dialogues.speaker: SARATOGA ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: »..The quarter mile time, a brisk 23 and four tenths. Turcotte is content to let Red roll along in last place, and mud splattering his white silks. IN THE STANDS, PENNY WATCHES as Big Red fails to challeng once more; she's worried he'll never make a move. Page 46 of 113  46. Turcotte guides him along, the horses easing toward the r as they plow down the backstretch. They’re all bunched in... no place for Red to move...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Red doesn’t have anywhere to go! I thought Turcotte was aggressive!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Make your move, Ronnie! Make your move! .--and as they pass the half-mile mark, Ronnie - surveyin everything in front of him - notices a tiny gap widening between a pair of horses just in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Red...go get em. Ronnie chirps, and there is a SUDDEN SURGE as Red’s shoul begin to pump and he bulls his way through the gap, knock the two horses aside with ease.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: That’s it! Quickly, ome by one, Secretariat overtakes the field, whi steady roar grows from the stands.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Come on Red! And Secretariat is absolutely rolling; a breathtaking sur

dialogues.speaker: SARATOGA ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ».-Secretariat surging past Court Ruling and now Blackthorn! The assault on the frontrunners is shockingly fast; he bl by the other horses like they were nags.

dialogues.speaker: SARATOGA ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Secretariat pulling away! The big horse pounds toward the finish line, crossing it lengths in front of the challengers...

dialogues.speaker: SARATOGA ANNOUNCER, (V.O0.)
dialogues.text: Secretariat with an impressive win! And as Lucien and Miss Ham applaud, Penny glances at the other owners; they toast her, and she smiles. Page 47 of 113  47. EXT. SARATOGA - WINNER’S CIRCLE - A FEW MINUTES LATER And now the WINNER’S PHOTOGRAPH is being taken: Penny and the entire team (Lucien, Ronnie, Miss Ham, Eddie) surroun the victorious horse as the flashbulbs pop. FROM PENNY’S Pov, it’s all harsh light and noise. Lucien is happy; he notices Ronnie’s silks are covered in dirt.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You look like you finished last!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I was there long enough! Secretariat, full of pride and the fire of victory, is actually turning his head toward each photographer. Nack Beyer are among the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Is it just me, or is that horse posing?

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Horses don’t-- He stops scribbling as he sees: Snap. Pose. Snap. Pose. Nack loves it, and starts scribbling again, furiously.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: (mumbling as he writes) “...the owner hates attention; the horse loves it...” And then Secretariat does something even more surprising: this dominating beast of a racehorse, fresh from humiliat a herd of hot-blooded rivals, turns his huge, filthy head places it like a baby against Penny’s chest. She cradles with exquisite tenderness; the photographers go crazy. Pe closes her eyes, shutting them out. But as the reporters leave and the grooms lead Secretaria away, Penny and her group watch with surging excitement.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He knocked those other horses out of the way like they were sparrows! I never saw a two-year-old do that!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You see the way he struts? He locks at the competition like, "Is this all you’ve got?” Page 48 of 113  42.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: I think he walks like... like a woman with big boobs! They all gawk at her...howl with laughter. We launch into MONTAGE OF VICTORIES: Secretariat blasts past one finish line after another (always starting dead last), and Penny back in the winner’s circle, receiving a different set of flowers every time; and each time Secretariat poses, then nuzzles Penny and ruins another new dress. Ronnie’s white silks are covered in mud after every victory.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Secretariat wins by five lengths! ...Secretariat by three lengths! »Secretariat by seven! ...Secretariat wins! ».-Secretariat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We smash out from the string of wins as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny walks alongside Secretariat, holding one of the lea along with Eddie, as the horse heads back to the barn. Be and Nack walk with her; she's stiff, struggling to be nat with two of the best reporters in all of racing.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Seven wins in four months. There's talk he could be Horse of the Year.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well... He’s... done everything we've asked of him.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: But the sons of Bold Ruler have all faded as 3-year-olds. And the Triple Crown races are much longer. Penny smiles, volunteering nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s extremely rare for a 2- year-old to be considered for Horse of the Year, but they’re still big kids at that age, they haven’t proven their full potential.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's true. Page 49 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks 4S.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: What’ve you learned about the horse? It's easier for her to talk about the horse; she softens.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: ++-He loves to run. Likes to come from behind--nerve wracking for me, but his fans love it. And... he's a ham. You've seen him show off.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: You really think he knows what he’s doing? Secretariat looks directly at him; it’s spooky.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me--Beyer’s the one who says you can’t run distances. They laugh, but Beyer presses the point to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: You do acknowledge the issue, right? That speed and endurance don’t go togeth-- A splattering sound, like a hose squirting on concrete, interrupts; Beyer looks at his shoes, then at the horse.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: No way... Nack laughs and starts scribbling again, loving this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebration time. Penny, Lucien and Ronnie are wrapping u dinner of cheeseburgers. Penny lifts her coke in the air.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: To Secretariat. Horse of the Year!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: And to Red’s owner, who took on the old boys.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You’re gonna have to take ‘em on harder next year, you know that, right? Page 50 of 113  50.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The races are longer.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Much longer.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The horses are faster.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Much faster. And every owner, every trainer out there will be trying to bring us down. Penny looks toward Turcotte.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I’1l be ready. A WAITRESS comes by and drops off the check to Penny. Luc and Ronnie make a half-hearted effort to reach for their wallets.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Here, let me help out with--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Sit down. She heads for the register, then sees Miss Ham entering.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: It’s your father, Honey. He’s had a stroke. I’11l get Lucien and Ronnie. INT. HOSPITAL ROOM — NIGHT Penny is alone at her father’s bedside. He’s comatose, monitors beeping, a ventilator softly sucking. Penny knee beside him; maybe she’s praying, or maybe the weight of l has bent her over. She lifts her head, looks at her fathe strokes his limp gray hair.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t think we‘ve left much unsaid, Daddy. I always knew where you stood. And I’m grateful for the way you showed me what it was to stand up in the world and live the way you believe. Page 51 of 113  51. Tears choke her for a moment, but Penny Chenery won’t let tears stop her.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: The big red colt won Horse of the Year, Daddy. I think he can go all the way. If he does, I hope you can see it. She kisses his head, and then realizes the heart monitors have ceased to beep. Penny lowers her head beside her father’s, and weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny is sitting alone at her father’s desk, trying to collect her strength; she looks up to see Jack entering. Then Hollis walks in just behind him; Penny stands and hu them both. Miss Ham has been at her desk, weeping with her own grief she moves to the door between her office and Penny’s, clo it so they all can have privacy.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I hadn’t had a chance to call. How’d you get here so fast?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I was already on my way.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Are-- Are the children all right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, they’re great. Or as great as they can be, without their mother around. He quickly softens his words, as if this is all about tak care of Penny and the children.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This is a terrible time, Penny... and we’re all here for you. I just hope you’ll come home now. Penny looks from Jack to Hollis to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: And you were already coming here to tell me that--before you heard about Daddy. Page 52 of 113  52

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Our children need a full-time mother. And I want a full-time wife. When your horse people call the house, they don’t ask for Mrs. Tweedy, they ask for Miz Chenery. Is that who you’ve become?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So you two have teamed up?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: It’s family business. And last time I checked Jack and your children were still part of the family.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hollis, you're my brother and I love you. But if you presume to judge my fitness as a wife or mother I’11 count you a stranger for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Penny! Hollis is only trying to talk sense.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Sense?! My father just died and you want to talk sense?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Your anger is exactly why we need this... intervention.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: We're in a crisis, Penny! What better time is there to talk sense? The word makes Penny’s eyes flame. Jack tries to sound reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hollis asked me to study the tax issues that would arise immediately upon your father’s death, and now they’ve hit us. At the current value of his estate, the inheritance tax will be at least six million. Page 53 of 113  53

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Six millions dollars, Penny. And neither of us has a fraction of that money.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So we sell the mares and yearlings.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: I had an appraisal done, and that won’t get us close to what we need. ..-But there is another option.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m not selling him. Hollis looks at Jack for help.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Due to his outstanding two year old season, if he were sold today, Secretariat would bring a price of seven million dollars. Enough to cover the tax bill by himself. (beat) Now I’m assuming the plan was to run him in the Triple Crown races. But if he were to lose just one of those three races his value would drop to two million. With no way to recover it.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: So we sell the horse. We'll talk about the farm later.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hollis, you try to sell that horse--

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: You just heard how much money we need!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Please, let’s settle down...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Look, we all respect what you did, but we’re out of time! Business hasn’t been great for me lately. The farm and the horses, they’re our father’s legacy. We play this wrong it could amount to nothing! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 54 of 113  54 HOLLIS (cont'd) It's time we get smart. Put the money into some good safe stocks.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Our father came from nothing. You know the story--his best Christmas was when he got a tangerine. He made every penny himself. And his legacy to me isn‘t money, it’s the will to win if you can and live with it if you don't! And TI will not dishonor him or myself by quitting now!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: If I have to challenge you in court, I will. And my lawyer tells me I’m likely to prevail. Jack can’t look Penny in the eye. She moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
