dialogues.text: Miss Ham! Would you step in here a moment, please? Miss Ham enters, with a clear sense of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Please tell Hollis and Jack about the provision Daddy left you.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Last year Mr. Chenery had me witness him signing a provision that while both of you are beneficiaries, dispersal of the farm would be left to Hollis. Decisions regarding the horses would be left to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Last year he already had dementia!

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: He was of sound mind when he signed it. I’d swear to it. In court.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Ham. Miss Ham, with the hint of a sad but steely smile, leaves them alone. Hollis is beaten, for now. Page 55 of 113  He leaves. 55.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Well Penny... you better find six million dollars before you race him again. And if he loses one of those races? You won’t see a cent. None of us will.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Then I’11 live with it.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Why?! Why do you need to?! For a past that no longer exists? Our father was a great man, but we can’t bring him back!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No, we can’t. And this isn't about going back, it‘s about life being ahead of you. And you run at it like a racehorse, as fast and as far as you can, because you never know how much life is there, unless you run.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Okay, Penny. Fair enough. But if you stumble and fall, you don’t just make us fools, you make us beggars. Now only Jack and Penny remain, in hard silence

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I always thought Miz Chenery and Mrs. Tweedy were the same person. Now Miz Chenery wonders why Mr. Tweedy believes he has to join my brother in an intervention. Jack walks out, leaving Penny alone again. INT. “THE MEADOW” — MAIN BARN - NIGHT Eddie walks Red out of his open stall and approaches Penn who needs to see the big horse for a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Eddie. How we doin’ tonight, Red? Page 56 of 113  56. He's the only one she can talk to right now. She rubs his nose, and the horse dips his head to her as if he underst her grief, and that she has bet everything, placed all he hopes, on him. (NOTE: We will sometimes use POV’s of the horse, to see the world and experience the story from his eyes.) Eddie stands back, watching them both.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Reckon you heard about Bull Hancock, Ma’ am?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Came home from your father’s funeral, and fell dead. Another dagger into Penny's soul; she doesn’t know how mu more she can take. Both Eddie and Red seem to sense this.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I can’t speak for the ways of God, Ma‘am... But your Daddy and Mr. Bull, they lifted each other up. The way you lift me up. And lift Red up. Everything living lives from its heart. I wish I could give you something that would lift yours up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You just did, Eddie. Thank you. He leaves her alone: Just Penny and Big Red. She looks at him; he locks back. His eyes are huge and bottomless, like windows into eternity. And there’s no way in the world she’s going to give up on him, or on herself. EXT. “THE MEADOW” - TRAINING TRACK - MORNING Penny and Seth walk, both holding steaming cups of coffee the early morning chill. Manhood has come early for Seth Hancock; he’s only 21, a tough time to lose a father.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: Thank you for calling, Miz Chenery. And for coming to the funeral. My father admired you tremendously. Page 57 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was mutual. ...I have a proposition for you, Seth. I want to sell Secretariat’s breeding rights.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: When he’s done with racing, and I’ve got a little more experience--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Before he retires. I want to syndicate his breeding rights now.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: All due respect, ma’am, but it doesn’t work that way.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It’s never been done, but that doesn’t mean it can’t work. We offer 32 shareholders exclusive breeding rights. We call it “a select opportunity.”

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: My father would’ve loved that phrase. How much per?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Two-hundred-thousand.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Two-- That’s more than anybody’s ever paid for a breeding share. A lot more.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That makes it exciting, Seth. And horse racing’s all about excitement. She stops and leans against the fence. Giving him time.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: He's been a great colt but he’s completely untried as a three-year- old, and the sons of Bold Ruler have never shown stamina.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: And that’s exactly what Ogden Phipps thought when he could've chosen my colt. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 58 of 113  58. PENNY (cont'd) Now I’ve got Secretariat. And he’s got a horse named Missed Opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: These people are smart with their money, they’1ll insist on a performance clause, and no son of Bold Ruler has ever won a single Triple Crown race. We’re talking a mile and a half, distances Secretariat hasn’t come close to running. He loses, you’1ll lose the money, the farm, the horse, everything. Penny surprises him: she looks right at him, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: This is a big deal. I’ve never attempted anything like it. Nobody has. You mind if I ask why you called me?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Your father helped me. And work is good for grief.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: You know, I told you he admired you; it was more than that. He told me he wished he was more like you. I think what he meant was, he wanted me to be like you. I’m in. They shake hands. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW" -— OFFICE — DAY A vapid-fire sequence as Miss Ham presses the “hold” butt on a five-line phone. Two other PHONES have been set up o the desk: one for Penny, one for Seth.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: I’ve got Howard Keck on line one, Bunker Hunt on line two. Ladies and gentlemen, start your engines. CLOSE as they push the buttons on each phone. Penny, standing, cradles the receiver to her ear...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mister Hunt, this is Penny Chenery. Page 59 of 113  59. EXT. “THE MEADOW” — MAIN BARN - SAME Eddie grooms Big Red, impressive in the morning sun...

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mister Keck? Seth Hancock. I’m calling about a select opportunity on Secretariat. --No sir, he’s not for sale. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Well sir, we’re moving to syndicate his breeding rights. (beat) Yes sir, right now. Before he retires. ...Yes sir, I know that. EXT. ’“THE MEADOW” - GRAZING AREA - DAY Secretariat grazes in the pasture, beautiful, magnificent

dialogues.speaker: PENNY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Dupont, it is a lot of money, but I wouldn’t be calling if I didn’t think he was worth it. (beat) Thirty two shares. A select opportunity. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” — OFFICE - SAME

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I understand. If you change your mind, I’d be happy to talk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We crawl across an ornate old desk to find JOHN W. GALBRE an old Kentucky gentleman who hasn’t worried about paying bill in his entire life.

dialogues.speaker: GALBREATH, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Seth, I been part’a lotsa deals but I ain’t never been asked to pay 200 grand for a breedin’ share. Nobody has. Tell Mr. Chenery’s little girl she’s pricin’ this colt like he already won the Triple Crown. Page 60 of 113  60. EXT. “THE MEADOW” — MAIN BARN — DAY Eddie squeezes a rubbing SPONGE (filled with HOT WATER) o Red’s shoulder blades. Steam rises to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Benjamin, you were there in Saratoga, you saw how good he looked. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE -— CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: All due respect, sir, but if he gets any better, you’1ll want to be in on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E.V. BENJAMIN takes a sip from a tumbler...

dialogues.speaker: E.V. BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: All due respect, little lady, but I’ve got a pretty good handle on where I want to be. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” -— OFFICE — DAY

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Yes Mr. Kleberg, it’s lotsa money. But my father used to tell me you gotta spend money to make it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT KLEBURG
dialogues.text: I'll give it some thought, alright?

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. You know where to reach me.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: Jock Whitney called. He’s ano. Paul Mellon’s on line three. INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW’ - OFFICE - DAY Penny, phone to her ear, glances at the sheet of paper th holds the tally. Page 61 of 113  61. The “yes” column doesn’t have a single mark in it yet. Th "no” and “maybe” columns are filling up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well sir, I'll hold a share for you in case you reconsider. Thank you for calling me back. Penny exchanges a glance with Seth and Miss Ham. No luck. EXT. MAIN HOUSE — FRONT PORCH — NIGHT Penny sits on the steps, discouraged. Miss Ham comes out sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: So how many times were you called little lady today? A tired smile from Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: They want to do it, I can feel it. But it’s outside what they’re used to, and they’re afraid.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: So I’ve been thinking. Maybe all we need to do is find one man willing to do this, somebody the others would feel safe in following. A big, big name. Penny looks at Miss Ham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ogden Phipps is staring across the booth table at Penny, two gunslingers playing poker, ready for a shoot-out.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You're asking me to spend 200 grand for a share in a horse that should be in my barn right now.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's right, Mr. Phipps, I am.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: No one’s buying yet, are they. »..as the waitress walks up. Page 62 of 113  463 62.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You two ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: (staring at Penny) We're still thinking about it. The waitress pours more coffee before she heads off.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You know that horse, the day we flipped that coin? She’s the nicest, best-tempered horse I've ever owned. Can’t run a lick. Now you’ve got the Horse of the Year, and I look foolish.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It’s not foolish to be unlucky.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tweedy, I don’t buy shares in untested three-year-olds. But... I know you're in a rough spot. I’11 buy him right now. Seven million dollars. All cash. Penny wasn’t expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I can’t do that, sir. I’m here to offer you a share in your horse's finest son. Most men, if they’d chosen wrong and lost this horse, wouldn’t even think of investing in him again, but you’re bigger than that. And you know that if he does what I think he'll do, his value will double, if not triple. And instead of being the man who lost Secretariat in the past, you’ll be the one who had the vision to lead investors in his future.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You do know what you’re saying. You’re guaranteeing that this horse will win the Triple Crown. The Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont. Three races, three states, in just five weeks. Hasn't been done in twenty five years. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 63 of 113  63. OGDEN PHIPPS (cont'd) Lot of good horsemen think it can’t be done anymore. Just understand, that is what you’re saying.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. That's exactly what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Eight million.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You’‘re that stubborn?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’m that right. The waitress walks up again.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You folks need some more time?

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: I think we’re ready. INT. KITCHEN - HOLLIS’S PLACE — MORNING Hollis, decked out in his morning bathrobe, pours coffee opens the morning paper; a headline catches his eye:

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS LEADS WAY
dialogues.text: INT. MAIN HOUSE AT “THE MEADOW” - OFFICE - DAY Penny, Seth and Miss Ham are celebrating; Seth’s reading a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: “The record setting deal means Secretariat is now literally worth three times his weight in gold, and creates expectations for horse and owner unrivaled since Citation’s Triple Crown run in 1948.” Page 64 of 113  64.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Please tell me that’s a small, local paper. Seth hands her the paper; it’s the NEW YORK TIMES.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So now we have to deliver. Lucien enters, in a hurry, turning on the television set.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You gotta see this. ON THE TELEVISION is a Sports Report, with footage of a brilliant black horse in the Winner’s Circle of the Santa Anita Derby.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ...and while Secretariat is drawing attention on the east coast, a similar story is unfolding out west. Sham, unbeaten since last year, was an easy winner in teday’s Santa Anita Derby, setting a new track record. Trainer Pancho Martin... On the set comes PANCHO MARTIN (45), a charismatic Cuban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this talk about Secretariat, he has never faced a horse as good as Sham. My horse is stronger, my horse is faster, and we won’t wait for the Derby to prove it. We’re going to the Wood Memorial. When Secretariat has to run as far as my horse did today, he’1l fade like the sunset. I guarantee it. Penny glances at Lucien; he locks away, deeply worried. T television shows Sham running away with the race.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: How good is his horse, Lucien?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: The further he goes, the faster he goes. He’s long and slender, a perfect distance horse. And Red just keeps getting bigger. We’ll find out at the Wood. ...I‘ve got work to do. Page 65 of 113  65. Lucien leaves; Seth gives Penny a brave smile and goes wi him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Seth.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: The Wood is in New York. You're gonna need a new dress. The phone rings; Penny answers, as Miss Ham studies the T article.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Penny Tweedy. INTERCUT AS NECESSARY, Jack in his law office, with a cop the New York Times Sports Section open to the article.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I saw the paper.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes, Seth did a great job.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'd like to say congratulations. But I’m a lawyer, and I know what performance guarantees mean.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Jack, I don’t know how to earn a reward without taking a risk--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Is it true Ogden Phipps offered you eight million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Horse people are worse gossips than the hens in a chicken coop.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It's true. And if Secretariat wins he'll be worth twice that. In Penny’s office, Miss Ham looks up from the paper, hear only Penny’s side of the conversation; she’s frozen by it Page 66 of 113  66.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’ve thought long and hard about this, Penny. You’re risking everything. Fair enough, it’s between you and Hollis I guess, though I would hope you’d consider the children.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Jack, I consider the children every day of my life--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I just mean, do what you want with your own money. But I won’t spend a cent of my money on what seems to me a crisis of identity that... that...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. Not a cent of your money. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean it like that, I meant-—

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I understood exactly what you meant. We’1l talk later. Penny hangs up. She glances at Miss Ham, then looks away.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: There are some words of wisdom that have sustained me through my darkest times... If you wouldn’t mind I'd like to share them with you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oh Miss Ham, I’m all ears.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: They are: “Good evening, K-Mart Shoppers.” As Penny’s face brightens from Miss Ham’s spirit-- CLOSE ON NEW HIGH HEELS, and great legs walking confident as we pan up on Penny, looking stunning in a new dress-—- a discount store. And we see that it’s the glow inside a woman, not the dress, that makes her beautiful. Miss Ham walks confidently beside her; they are Page 67 of 113  67. INT. AQUEDUCT RACE TRACK — PADDOCK AREA -— DAY Penny and Miss Ham are walking up to where Lucien (wearin yet another garish hat), Eddie and the other handlers are working to get ready. Penny rubs Secretariat's nose.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT P-A ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .--fifteen minutes to post, fifteen minutes. But Eddie's having trouble with the saddle girth.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: This saddle girth don’t fit.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: It's big enough for a Clydesdale!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, it ain’t big enough for Red. Maybe he’s still hiding some fat from the winter.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Horse look fat to you? Secretariat's ripped. Lucien has already pulled out his POCKET KNIFE and is making a new hole, muttering...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN, (IN FRENCH)
dialogues.text: Dix minutes pour écrire et je suis poingonnage un trou dans une circonférence.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Same thing I’ve done with every belt I’ve ever owned. And the sound of the Call to Post anticpates--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretariat and Turcotte move into the starting gate. TIT

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The horses now being loaded in for the big race of the day, the match- up between Secretariat and Sham... Page 68 of 113  68. IN THE STANDS: Penny, Lucien, Seth and Miss Ham wait. Pen turns to see a final-minute arrival: Ogden Phipps. He neds toward Penny. And just next to him, in the adjace box...is Pancho Martin and his colleagues. He gives her a nod, complete with a confident smile. AT THE STARTING GATE, the handlers load Secretariat, then Sham. Sham is beautiful, sleek, a natural distance runner His jockey, LAFITTE PINCAY, looks at Turcotte.

dialogues.speaker: PINCAY
dialogues.text: You gonna eat some dirt today, Ronnie.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The final test before the campaign for the Triple Crown...the first test of whether the big horse from Virginia can cover this distance. IN THE PRESS AREA: Nack and Beyer watch through binocular

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Time to see who’s got the real horse. IN THE STANDS: Penny glances again toward Ogden, and sees that he’s now been joined by two more investors: E.V. Benjamin and John Galbreath. They nod her way as well. DOWN IN THE STARTING GATE: Red shakes his head as if tryi to rid himself of something. Ronnie's never seen this.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Settle down boy.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The horses are in the gate... They hold for a beat, until the starting bell RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (CONT’D) ---and it is a clean start with Angle Light moving from the outside... ANGLE LIGHT bolts ahead and slowly cuts over from the out to take the lead at the rail. Page 69 of 113  69.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ».e-heading toward the rail. Step Nicely in second, Sham in good position, running third. Turcotte lets the big horse settle in - as he has so ofte the past - allowing him to fade back...

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Secretariat fading back to last. IN THE STANDS, Penny is reassuring Lucien, and herself...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: He always does this. It’s okay... The field plows into the first turn. Angle Light in first Sham just off his shoulder, Step Nicely in third. Penny, Lucien and Miss Ham watch... ».-Seth, Ogden and Pancho Martin do the same.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Angle Light holds the lead into the turn. Sham in perfect position... The horses move into the backstretch, Sham moving to the outside of him, waiting for Angle Light to burn out. Sham’s jockey, Pincay, sneaks a quick glance over his shoulder; Secretariat remains far behind; Ronnie flips do one of the dirt-shields on his goggles. Dirt everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: He's waiting for Turcotte to move. ON THE TRACK, Turcotte and Red are covered in dirt.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The pace now deadly slow into the final turn. Secretariat still holding back. Turcotte sees the opening in front of him, and finally ur him to run... and Secretariat has nothing. IN THE STANDS, we PUSH IN ON PENNY, her dreams crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: C'mon Red! Page 70 of 113  70.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Sham moves up! Secretariat is fading! ON THE TRACK, Secretariat labors, his breathing thin. Pin gives one more look over his shoulder at Secretariat, the chirps to Sham...and Sham surges ahead.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's Angle Light and Sham! Penny, Jack and Lucien; Seth, Miss Ham and Ogden...all th can do is watch helplessly as Secretariat fades back.

dialogues.speaker: AQUEDUCT TRACK ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Angle Light and Sham at the wire! Secretariat a stunning and distant third! And the aura of magic and invincibility that moments befo had surrounded both owner and horse has drained to disappointment, even anger. Phipps, Benjamin and Galbreat all turn and look toward Penny, before departing with...

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: We'll talk later. IN THE PRESS AREA: Beyer shrugs to Nack--—

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Just like his father after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pincay trots Sham - who looks perfect - toward the awaiti Pancho Martin. Spectators and reporters throng them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnificent! Magnificent! Next time we bury him even worse! Secretariat comes in on the other side, lathered, exhaust Eddie reaches for him as Ronnie dismounts, and the fans within shouting distance don’t hesitate to let Turcotte k how they feel...

dialogues.speaker: FAN
dialogues.text: Nice ride Turcotte! You do that with all your million dollar horses? Page 71 of 113  71.

dialogues.speaker: FAN
dialogues.text: You’re a bum! You don’t deserve him! Turcotte, covered with dirt and mud, ignores them all; Pe Lucien, Seth and Miss Ham arrive. Penny moves to the hors

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: He just didn’t fire. And he didn’t sound right.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: What the hell you mean, he didn’t sound right?!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: In his other races he breathed like a freight train--whoom, whoom! This time he sounded...thin. Penny pats Red on the neck, genuinely worried about him.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Make sure he’s okay, Eddie. (to Lucien and Ronnie) You two come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny unleashes on her trainer and jockey...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea what this does to us?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: «»..we just lost a race we could not afford to lose, we finished third! Third! In front of Mr. Phipps, Mr. Benjamin, Mr. Galbreath. What am I supposed to tell them?!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Tell them the truth. Tell them the horse had a bad day.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: We’re blaming the horse now? {to Ronnie) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 72 of 113  72. PENNY (cont'd) And what about you? How could you hold him back that long?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I rede him the same way I always do.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Then how does he finish the way he did? The only reason Sham didn't beat us even worse is that his jockey didn't believe what was happening, he was waiting for you! As if in tune with Penny’s fury, thunder rumbles overhead

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: If we weren’t leaving for Kentucky tomorrow, I'd fire both of you right now.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Do what you think’s right, ma’am, but there isn’t a jockey out there who knows this horse better than I do.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Ronnie had him in the right place. This wasn’t his fault.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well if it wasn’t the horse or Ronnie, whose fault was it? You better find out what happened today, and you better fix it. Because if that’s the best he can do at this distance, we're all finished! As Lucien and Ronnie watch Penny go, it begins to rain. J is waiting for her, at her car; he’s been watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny opens the door and gets in. Jack’s sitting behind t wheel. Silence for a beat, until...

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: Few days at home, get some rest, things’1l be better. Page 73 of 113  73

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I can’t. I have to go to Kentucky. Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JACK TWEEDY
dialogues.text: You said you were coming home for a few days, and the Derby isn’t for another--

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I know when the race is, Jack. I can’t do it. Not after today. I’ve got to find the problem with the horse and fix it. Or I’ve lost everything. The rainfall on the windshield is the only sound.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t mean everything, I mean...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Penny...I know you love the kids. When you’re at home you’re a fine- a great mother. And you can only be as good a wife as I can be a husband, and maybe I haven’t given you that much to come home to.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Jack--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It is what it is. If we don’t make it, the failure is at least as much mine as yours. But I just saw you go off on your jockey and your trainer. You’ve proven you know a lot more about horses than I do, but I have to ask you-- who are you mad at, really? Because if it’s me, I need to tell you something. Jack pauses, and Penny steels herself for a terrible moment...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want you to win. And win or lose, you’ve taught our children what a real woman is, and what it is to believe in yourself. I could never have taught them either of those things. I may have lost you. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 74 of 113  74. JACK (cont'd) But I’m proud of you...for becoming, once again, the woman I first fell in love with. He gets out of her car and walks away, into the rain. Pen sits alone in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls outside the stable area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the lights have been turned off for the night, th horses sleeping. But light spills from one stall. INT. AQUEDUCT RACE TRACK - STABLES - RED’S STALL - NIGHT CLOSE on Lucien's hands as he runs them over Secretariat' ankles, knees...trying to find any clue as to whether he’ hurt. Eddie and DOCTOR MANUEL GILMAN are doing the same o the other legs.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GILMAN
dialogues.text: Has he eaten anything?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Nothing. Horse has never missed a meal in his life.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GILMAN
dialogues.text: How much oats you usually give him?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Sixteen quarts. Twenty-five pounds of hay.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GILMAN
dialogues.text: A day? That’s more than a couple of pregnant mares would put away. They all stand. The vet tries to get Red to open his mout

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GILMAN
dialogues.text: Come on, I’m not gonna hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: He‘s not the one gonna get hurt, Doc. Secretariat rolls his head from side-to-side. Uncooperati Page 75 of 113  75.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GILMAN
dialogues.text: Settle down. Lucien, you want to give me a hand here?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He'll be okay, just give hima minute.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You afraid of him?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Horse is smart enough, he’s probably been waiting two years for me to get my hand near his mouth. Red finally holds steady as the vet runs his fingers alon the inside of Red’s mouth...until the horse flinches in p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lowest moment for Turcotte, who sits at a bar and tak sip of a beer. He’s running the race through his mind ove and over again. Unable to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same applies for Penny. She’s alone at the bar, a cup coffee and THREE SHEETS OF PAPER in front of her. Exhausted and stressed, she looks at the first sheet: The 1973 Kentucky Derby - Formal Entry - One and 1/4 mile She pulls it aside to see the second, and the third... The 1973 Preakness Stakes - Formal Entry - One and 3/16 m The 1973 Belmont Stakes - Formal Entry - One and 1/2 Mile The BARTENDER is answering the phone behind the bar; he m up to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Miz Chenery? A call for you... Penny moves to take it, already anticipating who it is.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (into phone) This is Penny. Page 76 of 113  76. INTERCUT OGDEN PHIPPS, from his home office.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You know I speak for everybody. One loss can happen. Two is non- performance.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: I’m sure you do. Penny hangs up the phone, and hangs her head, at her lowe She needs to reach out to someone; after a moment, she li the phone again and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of students, all aspiring to be Che Guevara, and dressed as counter-culture warriors, are preparing signs an anti-war march, when someone shouts—-

dialogues.speaker: HIPPIE STUDENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kate! Your Mother’s on the phone! He says Mother as if it’s a joke that anybody has one; Ka friends laugh. Kate moves to the phone and answers.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Honey. I just... wanted to see how you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Kinda busy right now, we’re getting ready for a march. ...You okay with that?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Kate, I-- Our politics can change but the need to speak up for what we believe, that doesn’t. I’m proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hey, I gotta go, can we talk later?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Sure, Honey. Page 77 of 113  47/24/89 15:46:48 > gb1 Page 478 77.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: »..You alright?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Sure, Honey. We’1l talk later. Penny hangs up. And Kate doss too, troubled by the tone i her mother’s voice. Kate rummages through the apartment m for a newspaper, and finds the Sports section and a racin headline: SECRETARIAT LOSES, with the sub-banner: A Not-S Super Horse? A Che wannabe moves up behind her, sees the horse racing article, and snickers.

dialogues.speaker: CHE WANNABE
dialogues.text: How bourgeois. The look Kate gives him is not unlike Penny's stare.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Up yours, Pig! BACK AT THE HOTEL BAR, Penny turns to see Lucien and Eddi

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Doc found a big abscess in Red’s lip. Probably hurting him all the way around the track. Nobody else saw it cause Red won't soften his mouth up for anybody but you.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Lucien...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Forget it. We've got the Derby to get ready for.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO BLACK
dialogues.text: »..and light spills in as the doors open on The Meadow Stables’ HORSE TRAILER, revealing a large cluster of REPORTERS, DERBY OFFICIALS and SPECTATORS.

dialogues.speaker: DERBY OFFICIAL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, from the Meadow Stables in Virginia... Page 78 of 113  78. EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS, KENTUCKY -— DAY

dialogues.speaker: DERBY OFFICIAL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .»..please welcome to the 99th running of the Kentucky Derby, Secretariat! Applause. Secretariat, wearing brilliant white ANKLE WRAP emerges from the horse trailer upon his arrival at...

dialogues.speaker: TWO WEEKS BEFORE DERBY DAY
dialogues.text: ...and we move up to take in the full sight of the big ho his demeanor and look somewhat dull and depressed...the abscess obviously bothering him. The amount of spectators and gawkers has now moved to a n much larger level... Eddie guides the horse down. Lucien, Penny, Seth, Ronnie Miss Ham meet Red at the bottom of the ramp and they tole a flurry of obligatory photographs... But the horse doesn raise his head to pose as he has so many times before. Na in the crowd, notices it. Penny rubs Red on the neck, quietly concerned. Eddie takes him away, and the foursome huddle for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: We'll take care of the horse, you take care of the reporters.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What? Me--?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I can’t think straight with those guys all over me.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: But I’m not...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: You’re as big a story as the horse. And if you want him fit you gotta keep those reporters away. And Penny starts to feel sick. The sound of hooves rises quickly, and... Page 79 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks 73. EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS - TRACK — TRAINING RUNS - DAY ..-Sham thunders along, alone, with blazing speed.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Another blistering workout for Sham today, while rumors continue to swirl about Secretariat's lackluster performance at The Wood Memorial... The trackside watchers (Nack and Beyer among them) click their stopwatches and compare times, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Sham’s burning up the track and Secretariat's missing. So's his owner.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: She’1l be at the press conference. The only thing she hates worse than talking about herself is backing down. INT. LADIES’ ROOM - DAY Penny, nearly hyperventilating, splashes cold water on he face, dries, and pinches her pale cheeks. She takes a dee breath and steps out, into-- INT. CHURCHILL DOWNS - BILLIONAIRE’S BALLROOM - DAY The big room where billionaires will dine before the Derb now arranged for a press conference, and she moves into t crowd; from PENNY’S POV, they all seem to be watching her She takes her seat at a long table, near Pancho Martin.

dialogues.speaker: DERBY ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tweedy and Mr. Martin are both here, so let's open for questions!

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: How are you two feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic! You've all seen Sham's workouts, he’s never looked better. The reporters wait; Penny says nothing. Page 80 of 113  BO.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Penny, Sham is turning in awesome workouts. When will Lucien work Secretariat?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Any concern Secretariat will run the same way he did in New York? Penny stares at Beyer as if dismayed by his stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes. The reporters wait again; a few of them chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Pancho, some people think Secretariat looked a little off at the Wood Memorial race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Looked a little off?” Racing is unforgiving, for trainers, horses or housewives. He glances at Penny; everybody in the room knows he’s bai her, but he draws just a flicker of a glance in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you what you’1l hear from the Secretariat people. Excuses. Excuses about The Wood. Excuses about their horse. More excuses than China’s got rice...and China’s got a lot of rice. The reporters scribble; Pancho’s bluster makes good copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s only one thing you’1l hear from me. We beat Big Red at The Wood. We'll beat him again here.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Any comment, Mrs. Tweedy? Penny shakes her head, feeling no need to respond. Page 81 of 113  Bl.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Penny, how much pressure are you feeling from your investors right now?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: It’s like every other all-or- nothing, multi-million-dollar gamble we housewives make every day. The reporters crack up, loving her; Penny glances at Panc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miz Tweedy didn’t hear, so I’11 make myself clear. Secretariat is going down. I guarantee it. Everyone’s looking at Penny. Waiting. They don’t wait lon

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Pancho’s starting to brag like a boxer. Maybe he plans to take up prize fighting after he finishes horse racing. ...But Sham’s got as much chance of beating Secretariat as Pancho has of beating Muhammad Ali. The reporters nearly levitate with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie works a HOT, DAMP TOWEL under Secretariat’s tender as Lucien and Charlie watch...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: How’s it look?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Same. Still hasn’t eaten.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna have Ronnie take him out in the morning. See how he does. EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS -— TRACK -— DAY Ronnie lets Red roll...but he’s not rolling. And the soun of his breathing is noticeably thin. Page 82 of 113  B2. He passes the same trackside watchers (Beyer and Nack amo them) and the stopwatches click again.

dialogues.speaker: KENTUCKY HORSEMAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’ve been training horses for thirty years and I guarantee you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of "INSIDERS” giving their opinion to reporters

dialogues.speaker: KENTUCKY HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: ..-there’s something wrong with that horse. Something serious.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDER
dialogues.text: He’s walking wide in front. You ask me, that’s a sign of bad knees.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDER
dialogues.text: Bone chips in his knees, no question about it.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDER
dialogues.text: Ankles. Has to be. I’ve talked to a half dozen trainers and they say the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pancho poses with Sham. PHOTOGRAPHERS snap away...

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And while Pancho Martin is brimming with confidence, the pressure continues to build on the Secretariat camp. The latest to express doubts? Vegas oddsmaker Jimmy "The Greek” Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY "THE GREEK” holds court at a local bar... JIMMY "THE GREEK” SNYDER I just don’t like Secretariat's chances. I said before The Wood he had no right to be favored over Sham. Now I’m hearing the horse might be lame. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 83 of 113  83. JIMMY "THE GREEK” SNYDER (cont'd) T’1l bet if you looked in that stall right now you’d see ice packs on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even more reporters follow Penny now; she’s a great story She’1l never enjoy interviews, but she’s acclimating.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: (trying to get the next question in...) Penny! Penny!

dialogues.speaker: DERBY REPORTER
dialogues.text: So where's the name Penny come from?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s actually Helen, but that was my mother’s name, so we needed something different. I guess that kind of nickname was popular then: Penny, Buffy, Gigi--they ought’a shoot us all. Big laughs; the reporters are falling in love with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twin spires are silhouetted against the moonlight. Al is suddenly quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucien nurses a cup of coffee as he leans on the rail, staring at the ground in front of him. Worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny walks up to Red’s stall. Eddie’s asleep on a cot ju outside the door. Red comes over to see her. She rubs his neck and pulls a PIECE OF CARROT from her pocket. He snif but doesn't take it. Penny exhales, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it says about either of us, but I’d rather talk to you right now than to anybody else. So here’s the deal. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 84 of 113  B4. PENNY (cont'd) I’ve never asked you to run this far. But you’re the fastest and the smartest horse in this race. Don’t lock away from me, you know what I'm talking about. Which is exactly what he was doing, till he stops and loo at her again.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: There's no second chance here, and it's time to step up, you hear me? He’s staring right at her. No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: All right, then. See you in the morning. EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS, KENTUCKY -— DAWN Brilliant sunrise. Another day to hope... INT. CHURCHILL DOWNS —- STABLE 21 - DAY Eddie walks toward Red’s stall, optimistically carrying a PAIL OF FEED. Eddie slides open the door and walks in. Red’s standing up as he puts the pail down and pats the b horse...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Morning Red. How we feeling today? «..then wanders over to the feed bin. And that’s when Edd notices that the feed bin is now completely empty. He turns and sees Red’s nose is buried deep in the pail.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Watch out, Kentucky! Big Red has arrived! RISING IN THE BACKGROUND: the strains of “MY OLD KENTUCKY HOME,” accompanied by the more than a hundred thousand fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Secretariat’s checkerboard blinkers as he stops the end of the breezeway, the last moment before he emerg into Derby Day pandemonium. The horse looks out over the track, the crowd, as if surveying the situation. Page 85 of 113  85. Eddie holds him by the shank lead. Charlie sits on a SILV PONY that will accompany them onto the track.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Let him sit for a minute, Eddie. He likes to take it all in. Ronnie rubs the big horse’s neck as Secretariat looks one and then the other, adjusting to the setting. The sound is palpable as Turcotte and Charlie exchange a quick, nervous glance. Red gives a toss of his head. And Ronnie nods toward Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Safe trip, boys. ».e-he unclips the lead, sending them out onto...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest stage they’ve yet seen. Everything is big tod big HATS, big MINT JULEPS. Crowds packed in the stands an in the infield.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: IN THE STANDS, nervously waiting... Penny, Lucien, Miss Ham, Seth and Ogden Phipps. John W. Galbreath and E.V. Benjamin stand right behind him. Ogden leans forward to tell Penny...

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Big day, Mrs. Tweedy. IN A NEARBY BOX: Pancho Martin stands (with a HALF DOZEN so of his COLLEAGUES), awaiting the race as well.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PRESS BOX
dialogues.text: Nack and Beyer, scribbling notes, trying to maintain the outer calm that fails most reporters on this day. EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS - TRACK -— DAY The GATE HANDLERS reach out for Red as he draws near... ».-but a horse already in the gate, TWICE A PRINCE, rears and causes a commotion. Instead of allowing Secretariat t be drawn into the gate, Turcotte turns him away (back tow Charlie); waiting for the other horses to settle down. Page 86 of 113  86. A couple of seconds later, Turcotte turns Red back toward gate and tells the GATE HANDLER--

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Take it easy with him. Little anxious today.

dialogues.speaker: GATE HANDLER
dialogues.text: You got it, Ronnie. And the starter, amidst the chaos, reaches for the extens to the bit and soothes the big horse. Bam!--the gates sla behind him, causing Red to toss his head slightly...just he did before The Wood.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Settle down... The announcer, CHIC ANDERSON (pronounced “Chick”)...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They're at the post. Secretariat throws his head just a bit. .»..as Ronnie reaches down and takes a handful of mane (s holding the rein) to steady himself at the furious start. The spectators anticipate...

dialogues.speaker: RIITITINNNNNGGGGG
dialogues.text: ...and the gates fly open. Fifteen horses surge onto the track; the roar from the spectators lusty and immediate. Overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And they’re off in the 99th running of the Kentucky Derby! Shecky Greene, as expected, sprinting to the front of the pack. Royal and Regal just behind, Gold Bag quickly moving into third. Secretariat, as he’s done in all of his races, drops to t rear of the field.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sham and a dozen others moving into striking position. Secretariat is at the back of the pack. Penny and Lucien watch, dreading a repeat performance of Wood. Page 87 of 113  B87. Turcotte rides the big horse as calmly as ever, studying dirt-clod-tossing brigade ahead of him... .»..seeing nothing but trouble on the rail, seeing zero openings in front of him... He lumbers along...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fast first quarter in 23 and two... Turcotte eases Secretariat to the outside, still in last. Sham, with Pincay onboard, slices into third place with a brilliant surge.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sham moving up into third, Gold Bag just in front of him as they clear the half mile... Red starts moving up..and it looks, even though it’s earl the race, that he’s running better; he’s now in ninth pla

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: {to herself) Come on Red... Nack and Beyer raise their binoculars to watch... ++eas Pincay moves Sham into second place.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: On the outside now is Sham, running easy as he moves into second, the three quarter time a speedy 1:11 and four...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s my boy. »»eand as they sail into the far turn... the horses leani toward the rail... Turcotte notices something: Red’s breathing sounds like a FREIGHT TRAIN--deep, resonant. Whoosh. Whoosh.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Secretariat still well back of the leaders. Penny rises on her tip-toes in hopes of seeing better. Th sound of the crowd escalates... Page 88 of 113  BB.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Sham has taken the lead!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Gotta move him, Ronnie. Gotta move him now! But Secretariat lags far back of the leaders. Pancho nods sure of victory. Penny and Lucien are dying.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I’m getting out of here. He starts to go, unable to watch; Penny grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You’re gonna stay here and take this with me. Penny can barely watch, but she has to... ON THE TRACK, Turcotte chirps to Secretariat, and the whooshing sound gets even deeper and more powerful.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. Go! Turcotte moves Red into fourth place, into third (on the outside). But he still trails SHAM, LEADING THE FIELD and running beautifully as they head into the stretch.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Final quarter mile! Laffit Pincay, in perfect position, chirps to Sham...

dialogues.speaker: LAFFIT PINCAY
dialogues.text: Gol Gol And for a brief second, Pincay is sure he is riding the D winner. Until...he glances to the ground on his right... »..and sees a shadow approaching. Then he hears breathing Whoom! Whoom! Pincay glances over his shoulder... .».-and the big horse is right there. For a hundred yards they run right next to each other...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It’s Sham and Secretariat! Neck and neck! Page 89 of 113  B89. Churchill Downs shakes with the realization that each fan seeing exactly what they came to see: the two greatest thoroughbreds in racing, locked in a dead-heat.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Come on, Red...Come on, Red... COME

dialogues.speaker: ON
dialogues.text: Secretariat now pulls away from Sham. One length. Two. The spectators go crazy as Red sprints down the stretch, opening an even greater lead. Even Nack and Beyer fall victim to the sight...

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: C’mon! ...Secretariat CROSSES THE FINISH LINE. And there is a celebration like none other in the stands and the infield Penny reaches out for Lucien, Miss Ham, Seth... Phipps looks at Penny and gives her a smile. It’s a joyou moment for all. And then, the icing...

dialogues.speaker: DERBY P-A ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, Secretariat with an unofficial time of one minute, 59 and two-fifths seconds! A new Kentucky Derby record! EXT. CHURCHILL DOWNS - WINNER’S CIRCLE - A FEW MINUTES LA CLOSE on the ceremonial BLANKET OF ROSES being draped on dirt-covered horse. Penny cradles the TROPHY...Secretaria standing tall just behind her shoulder; a terrific-lookin pair. The team surrounds them. The buzz of the crowd still provides an electric backdrop The CBS ANCHOR OF THE BROADCAST interviews Penny (which Churchill Downs can hear as well)...

dialogues.speaker: CBS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Penny, it’s been twenty five years since horse-racing’s had a Triple Crown winner. Is this the horse that finally breaks that streak?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: We still have a lot of work to do. But at least we’ve given ourselves a chance. Page 90 of 113  90. And it’s in that moment that Secretariat turns his mud an dirt-covered head and brushes up against Penny, who was decked out in spring colors a second ago... ...and she doesn’t mind a bit, rubbing his neck.

dialogues.speaker: CBS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Penny. The fastest Derby ever. Here’s hoping we see the same thing two weeks from now at the Preakness! A roar from the crowd as Penny, smiling from ear-to-ear, her hand over Red’s dirt-covered nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The race is already underway. A HALF-DOZEN HORSES thunder their way toward the CAMERA as they head down the stretch toward the first turn...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ecole Etage in first, Torsion now second, followed closely by Sham. Secretariat is last once again as they head toward the first turn. The smile is gone as Penny is forced once again to endure watching Red run along in last place. She’s surrounded by the same group that attended the Derby. Turcotte guides Secretariat into familiar position: sligh outside of the pack, content to wait...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sham now making a steady bid as he moves into second. Pincay eases closer to Ecole Etage, Sham running with his typical combination of grace and power. Turcotte moves Red closer to OUR NATIVE.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A sluggish pace as the field now heads through the first turn. IN THE STANDS, Penny and the group watch... Page 91 of 113  ol. »..as the horses roll along. But Ronnie sees that he has risky opportunity--a narrow gap between horses.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Careful... The horses lean into the turn, and that’s when Ronnie cal on Red to...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Okay, Red...go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see the big horse, on his side, snoring in his sta All is fairly dark as we move along the slumbering mass, arrive upon... ».-Penny, Lucien and Ronnie sitting at a table (illuminat by a dim light up above), each with a STYROFOAM CUP OF COFFEE.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: »..so that’s when it happened.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: That’s when it happened, yes ma’am. Every one of those horses was holding back, I mean really holding back, afraid to take the lead. All packed in, right on the rail. EXT. PIMLICO - TRACK — DAY .».-and the next ten seconds are jaw-dropping. Big Red mo to the outside...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Here comes Secretariat! Moving fast, swinging to the outside. He’s going for the lead! ».eand Red passes every horse in the field in a matter of seconds. Blowing right past Sham.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All my years of riding, I‘ve never moved past that many horses that fast. Dead last to first in 200 yards. Page 92 of 113  92.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: »..with more than half the race left, don’t forget. EXT. PIMLICO - TRACK — DAY Secretariat pounds along the backstretch, thundering ahea the field. Two lengths ahead of Sham.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Any other race we'd have been home free, but I knew Sham was still back there. I wasn’t worried about anyone else. The two horses storm ahead, Secretariat still holding a steady lead over his powerful rival. INT. PIMLICO - STABLES —- NIGHT {HOURS AFTER THE RACE)

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What was Red telling you?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Just let me run, boss, don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red drags Sham into the final turn, another classic duel between these magnificent beasts.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The one thing you can never give a horse is a killer instinct. They’ve either got it or they don’t. And with Red, I’ve never once had to use the whip. FROM THE STANDS: Penny watches as Red heads for home.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: So we’re in the stretch and that’s when I hear it... Page 93 of 113  93

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pincay lashing his whip...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ».-Pincay going to the whip, trying to get one last burst out of Sham. .».-and Sham is moving. But Red pins his ears back and surges...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But Red? He just starts moving on his own. Two lengths ahead, then three. Everything in control, not a worry in the world. +..and the crowd roars as Secretariat cruises toward the finish line. Winning.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: What about you? You ever turn your head back to see? Just even a little?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: No. Never look back. A hint of a smile from Penny.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So one more win. How do we get it?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Well, ma’am, that’1l require one more decision from you.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: {to Lucien, in French) You sure you want to talk about this now?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN, (IN FRENCH)
dialogues.text: When else should we talk about it? The race is in three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (IN FRENCH)
dialogues.text: Let her celebrate. There's no hurry to... Page 94 of 113  94.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY, (IN ENGLISH)
dialogues.text: I know the race is in three weeks. But we need to make a decision now. Lucien glances at Ronnie, then asks Penny...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: So all this time you understcod...?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Oui. »..they all smile. Lucien has grown to really like her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: So in the last twenty five years, seven horses have won the Derby and the Preakness, but nobody’s won the Triple Crown. That’s because of the Belmont. Mile and a half, the longest race these horses will ever run. Red won the Derby and the Preakness in record time, coming from behind in both. You gotta figure he knows he'll burn out if he goes too fast and too early.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Conventional wisdom is to rest him. Let him recover from the last two and store up energy for the Belmont.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I never believed conventional wisdom is any such thing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Then I say we work him. Run him hard. Harder and faster than ever. Penny knows this decision could cost everything. Or win i

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Miz Chenery, in all my years of training horses, I’ve never seen one with his kind of appetite for running. It’s like he can’t get enough. I work him one day, he runs faster the next. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 95 of 113  95. LUCIEN (cont'd) I know how much you need him to win this race, and there’s a chance we could be draining every drop of gas out of his tank. But I don’t think BO.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s find out what he’s got. INT. BELMONT PARK - CLUB ROOM — DAY REPORTERS are shoulder-to-shoulder, Nack and Beyer among them. Penny and Pancho Martin sit at a long table up fron (Lucien, Ronnie and Laffit Pincay are there as well.

dialogues.speaker: DERBY REPORTER
dialogues.text: Mister Martin! Secretariat’s beaten your horse twice now. What makes this race different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any good horseman will tell you, Secretariat is built for speed and Sham is built for distance. Mrs. Tweedy thinks her horse has somehow magically inherited both. This will be the race that proves her intuition only goes so far. Penny doesn’t take the bait. Yet.

dialogues.speaker: DERBY REPORTER
dialogues.text: Penny, what about all the attention Secretariat's receiving? Covers of Newsweek, Time magazine...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Let me tell you something! He holds up the latest copies of TIME, NEWSWEEK, SPORTS ILLUSTRATED, all with Secretariat on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this talk about “Super Horse?” Sham broke the Derby record too! He ran the second fastest Derby and the second fastest Preakness ever. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 96 of 113  96. PANCHO MARTIN (cont'd) Ever! We were right there with the red horse every step of the way! Nack glances at Beyer, both of whom know it’s true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we run the longest of the Triple Crown Races. And when we're done you'll be calling Sham the “Super Horse!”

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Any comment, Penny?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I'd have to say I agree with Mr. Martin completely. His horse did run the second fastest ever. The reporters laugh. Lucien and Ronnie stifle a grin. Pancho Martin simmers as the flashbulbs pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretariat (Ronnie onboard) runs a training workout, fly through the morning chill... .»..the TRACK REPORTERS’ stopwatches click in unison, rig through to Lucien, Penny and Seth; who hold stopwatches t

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Three quarters in 1:12.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Looks good.

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: You sure you want to send hima mile next time out? Lucien and Penny give him a look. Stick with the plan bud

dialogues.speaker: SETH HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Just asking. EXT. BELMONT PARK — TRACK — MORNING A few days later. Red thunders past the stopwatches again Click, click, click.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Are we working him too fast? Page 97 of 113  97. Lucien doesn’t reply, jotting the time down in his note p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big horse's breath is visible against the cold air as strides along. Powerful. Awesome. The stopwatches click again... EXT. BELMONT PARK — DAY ...into the clicking of CAMERAS at a PHOTO OPPORTUNITY. P stands off Red‘s shoulder as PHOTOGRAPHERS call out for b of them... ».eand she is smiling graciously, the perfect complement the dynamic, powerful, and yes, posing animal next to her Eddie holds the lead. EXT. BELMONT PARK — BURGER BARN AREA — NIGHT ESTABLISHING of the festival area that’s set up every Jul near the front entrance to the track. Penny’s on a pay phone, talking brightly, cheerfully.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: {into phone) Okay, Sweetheart! I love you! She hangs up. She sits down on a bench. Miss Ham walks up with a couple of cups of coffee and joins her.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAM
dialogues.text: How you holding up? When Penny doesn’t answer, Miss Ham lifts Penny’s sunglas and sees her eyes rimmed with tears.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Chris has a baseball game today; he pitches, and when he’s wild he gets down on himself, and then nobody knows how to talk to him but me. John’s making airplane models the other kids ignore. The girls are... teenaged girls. And I’m not there with them. Page 98 of 113

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Daddy worried about exactly the same thing. Did you ever doubt he loved you?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Not for a second. Miss Ham nods: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nack and Beyer are finishing breakfast and pouring over t RACING FORMS spread out on their table.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: You ever seen a horse run training times like this before?

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Maybe Penny and Lucien are geniuses, and Big Red won’t run out of gas like his father did. But Pancho Martin’s right, his horse ran a faster Derby and a faster Preakness than any horse in history except Secretariat, and Sham has perfect genes for a mile and a half. He’s built for the Belmont. And he’s rested. It’s gonna be 95 degrees out there, and Sham’s a California horse, used to heat. Pancho’s smart. He'll push the pace, try to get the big horse to fight for the lead too soon. If he does, he could unravel like he did at the Wood.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: You think Secretariat could lose?

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: I know he could lose the race. I just hope they don’t lose the horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights from the Belmont structure glow in the night s Page 99 of 113  Iturned my screenplay inte a MP3 and It's DUAKING DOONEY) = thar's THE Facr, sacks 99. INT. BALLROOM — NIGHT The annual Belmont Ball. WAITERS and WAITRESSES make thei way through the crowded room as a SINGER croons on stage. Penny is standing alone, taking it all in, just as Secretariat does before a big race. Ogden Phipps sees her and moves up.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Phipps.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Penny. You must find this quite exciting.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I do. I hope you do too.

dialogues.speaker: PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Yes. But I've been here before. In the last thirty years, seven horses have won the first two legs of the Triple Crown, and failed on the third. I try not to forget that. »..Good luck tomorrow, He leaves her haunted, sobered. Penny turns...and finds Kate! She’s beautiful, in an elegant gown, stepping into world for the first time as a woman.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Kate! They embrace, Kate beaming, elegant.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You’re right on time. And you look so beautiful. All grown up.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You look beautiful too, Mom. All grown up. And suddenly everything between them is different, change forever. Kate takes her mom into another embrace.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I am so, 80 proud of you. Page 100 of 113  100. And she breaks away to let Penny see the rest of her fami the three other children, and Jack--all dressed for the b The children run up and embrace Penny in a family hug. Ja holds back, watching respectfully, even reverently. Then the children sense their parents need a moment alone and Sarah ushers them off toward the refreshments. Jack steps up to Penny.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They're growing up. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Yes. Kate’s stunning in that gown.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I wish I'd bought her a gown sooner. And I wish I’d bought yours. But I couldn’t have done as well for you as you've done for yourself. (beat) Good luck tomorrow, Penny. We’re proud of you. All of us are. Jack starts away.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Jack! ...Thanks for bringing them. Thanks for coming yourself. He smiles softly and moves away, leaving Penny in a bittersweet silence. She turns...to find Lucien. Dressed up. Handsome.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Tweedy.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Mister Laurin. You’re looking very handsome tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I left my hat at home, just for you. He reaches into his pocket...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: But I brought something else. A mutual friend of ours gave it to me. Page 101 of 113  101. .--and he hands her the coin that Bull used at the Arling Club.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I especially like the “heads” side. She takes it, then waits a beat before...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: You're the best I could‘ve hired for him, Lucien.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: And you’re the best owner I ever Baw.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Ah. Lucien dit c’vrais. Lucien grins; Penny smiles. Then we PUSH IN ON HER as she takes a deep, slow breath to fight the tension...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are on but the cavernous stands are completely empty, and a few workmen groom the racing surface, making perfect for tomorrow's race. Penny stands silently at the rail, gazing out over the endless track; she looks more a than ever. EXT. BELMONT PARK -— STABLES - NIGHT Penny moves up to Red’s stall; Eddie stands from his cot, leaves her alone with her horse. He’s lazily munching foo not looking at her now; she knows she’s talking to hersel

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I’ve been walking around here wondering if it really matters what happens tomorrow. But I’ve realized something I need to say. I've already won. I've made it here. I didn’t quit. Secretariat lifts his head, and moves to her. She looks a him, hoping with all her heart that he somehow understand

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I've already run my race. Now you run yours. Page 102 of 113  102. EXT. BELMONT PARK — DAWN A light coating of dew and fog covers the infield of the empty race track. It looks utterly endless. TITLE:

dialogues.speaker: THE BELMONT STAKES JUNE 9, 1973
dialogues.text: The voice of a RADIO ANNOUNCER...

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: A record crowd is expected today as Secretariat makes his bid for horse racing immortality. The race is scheduled for 5:38 this afternoon, forecasters predicting temperatures in the mid-90's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Nack sleeps in his car, the window rolled down. The nickering of a horse awakens him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie and Charlie lead Red to the walkway, as Lucien watc

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Careful with him. Just let him walk off his nerves. Nack scurries in and stands near Lucien...

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Horse is fired up.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: He knows what's happening, that’s for sure. DOWN THE WALKWAY: A YOUNG STABLE GIRL accidentally drops METAL BUCKET... ».-and the clanging sound echoes through the walkway. Red rears, pawing his hooves at the sky. Frightening. Awesome

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Keep hold of him! Hold him! Eddie and Charlie try to hold him, but the horse is wound up...rising to the sky once again. Majestic. Page 103 of 113  103.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Alright, put him back in! Before he hurts himself.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE DAVIS
dialogues.text: Hurts himself? Horse is gonna hurt me. Nack is scribbling notes faster than ever. Shaking his he

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Ohhh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny is looking in the mirror, putting the finishing tou on her wardrobe for the day. But there is one last touch that she has waited months to wear... She reaches for the LUCKY PIN her father gave her. And puts it on. The sound of a massive crowd begins to rise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: »..as the spectators move through the turnstiles. Setting shop along the rail. Staking out their spots. There are SIGNS everywhere: “Good Luck Secretariat” in bl and white, "Go Red/” in red, white and blue. "Secretariat Triple Crown!”

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Pancho Martin gives Pincay his final instructions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go hard for the lead, draw him up with you. If he does? He’s ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a pair of hands...holding the most garish HAT ye WIDER to reveal Lucien, sitting with Ronnie in a separate section of the room.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Don't send him to the front, but don‘t choke him either. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 104 of 113  104. LUCIEN (cont'd) Just remember, we’ve got a mile and a half we’ve got to cover. Don’t... you know, don’t...

dialogues.speaker: TURCOTTE
dialogues.text: Let him burst his heart?

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I just... Bonne chance.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Bonne chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pulls the familiar blue and white checkerboard blin tight on Secretariat’s head. The horse’s nostrils flare, he’s ready to rumble. His breathing is already audible. Eddie’s securing the massive saddle girth.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Lotta track today, Red. Lotta track. EXT. BELMONT PARK -— STANDS -— DAY Penny’s standing up, already nervous. She holds a PAIR OF BINOCULARS, craning her neck toward the area where the thoroughbreds will enter... .».-then notices a gentleman is now standing next to her, looking at a RACING FORM. Hollis. Penny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Wasn’t sure you’d make it.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLIS
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, got a tip on a horse. They share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fans everywhere. Pancho is out walking Sham, striking as always. A murmur rises as SECRETARIAT comes into view... The sunlight spills onto his copper skin, and he’s magnificent. Secretariat stops and looks at Sham and the other horses as if they aren’t worthy of him; Nack sees t Page 105 of 113  105. SECURITY GUARDS and COPS hold the FANS back as Eddie guid Secretariat around. A GIRL 6 years old holds an INSTAMATI CAMERA to her eye to take a picture of Red as he walks by »..and he turns toward her as she clicks the photo. She pulls the camera down...and takes a step backwards toward father. ».the bugle call to post sounds... »..and Red hears it: shaking his head as if he can't wait get out to the track; his eyes sharp, his muscles taut.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Got two bucks I can borrow? Ronnie moves alongside Red (Lucien is there as well) and gets a leg-up into the saddle. He pats Red on the neck. Pincay gets the same boost from Pancho Martin, and the tw jockeys exchange a quick look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretariat emerges onto the track and there is a thunder roar from the hundred-thousand fans on hand. He high step out, a portrait of equine royalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anticipation is running white hot. Nervous applause from key spectators: Penny and her entire family. Miss Ham. Hollis. Seth. Ogden Phipps... .--E.V. Benjamin, John Galbreath, and a couple other SYNDICATE MEMBERS. Everyone’s here on this day.

dialogues.speaker: OGDEN PHIPPS
dialogues.text: {leaning over) Very big day, Mrs. Tweedy. EXT. BELMONT PARK - STARTING GATE — DAY Secretariat is loaded in first (in the rail slot), the ne pair of horses going in next to him as the roar from the crowd grows. Page 106 of 113  106.

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Only six horses in the field today, many of the owners conceding that this is, in effect, a match race between Secretariat and Sham. The gate handlers yell out their instructions...

dialogues.speaker: GATE HANDLERS
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait! Hold on now! Okay! IN THE STANDS: Penny squeezes a rolled-up PROGRAM tight. Waiting, worried. Lucien is now in the stands, beside her IN THE STARTING GATE: Ronnie grabs a tuft of mane (in SLO MOTION, upping the tension). Pincay looks over...

dialogues.speaker: PINCAY
dialogues.text: You gonna eat a lot of dirt today.

dialogues.speaker: TURCOTTE
dialogues.text: Don‘t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O0.)
dialogues.text: The field is at the post...Chic Anderson with the call. EXT. BELMONT PARK —- PRESS BOX — DAY Nack and Beyer stand as well, ready to witness history. N one is seated anywhere, the crowd electric. EXT. BELMONT PARK - STARTING GATE — DAY

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The horses now loaded in... SECRETARIAT’S NOSTRILS emit an audible whoosh... SHAM’S LEGS shudder with pent-up energy... The starting bell shrieks, the gates burst open, the hors surge out... ON THE TRACK, Secretariat surges RIGHT INTO THE LEAD! IN THE STANDS, ON PENNY: she’s surprised, concerned...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (to Lucien) Why's he going to the lead?! Page 107 of 113  107. Sham sprints hard, nudging ahead on the outside, all six horses within a length of each other on the first stretch .»..with Secretariat close on the rail, fighting to regai lead. Pancho smiles, seeing his strategy play out perfect

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT P-A ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: First quarter, 23 and three. 23 and three.

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: They're blazing! Pincay moves Sham out to the lead and he begins to pull further in front of the other horses...

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sham moving to the lead, easing his way to the inside of the track! But Secretariat picks up the pace as well. CHIC ANDERSON (V.0.) (CONT’D) But Secretariat picks up speed, denying Sham the rail! The two frontrunners are within a neck of each other, Sha still holding a slender lead, two magnificent horses roll

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT P-A ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Half mile, 46 and one. 46 and one. INTERCUT WITH THE STANDS AND THE PRESS BOX: Beyer watches through his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
dialogues.text: Too quick, way too quick!

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: Slow him down, Ronnie!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Easy, Red. But Secretariat is running silky smooth as he and Sham be to pull away from the field. Penny watches, while Pancho Martin gets a nod and a smile from the COLLEAGUE next to It's already a two horse race.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sham and Secretariat now moving ahead of the field... Page 108 of 113  108. CAMERA SLOWLY RISES as: the twin thunder of Secretariat a Sham’s hooves beat in pure rhythm as they lean toward the backstretch. Turcotte and Pincay keep pushing, scrubbing their reins i perfect synchronization, close enough that they could tou the other. Pincay looks out of the corner of his eye... ...and he moves Sham ahead with a chirp. Ronnie does the same and Secretariat draws even...

dialogues.speaker: NACK
dialogues.text: Big Red can’t take this pace. But the two jockeys are in their own world: unaware of pa or time, or the crowd. Only the opponent next to them.

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT P-A ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Three quarters, one oh nine and four. One oh nine and four. IN THE STANDS: Penny hasn’t blinked yet. Watching...hopin ON THE TRACK: Secretariat’s stride is solid. Ronnie glanc at Sham, hearing the black horse’s breathing..-.rapid and slightly high-pitched. He turns and listens to Red. And he hears a sweet, deep whooshing sound. Ronnie chirps...

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Come on, Red! And it’s in that moment that Ronnie and Secretariat move the lead... »..drawing a deafening roar from a hundred thousand delir racing fans.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Secretariat moving to the lead! Miss Ham knows it’s too soon. She cups her hands over her mouth as Lucien - furious - yells...

dialogues.speaker: LUCIEN
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Big Red’s hooves crushing into the soil, his wi shoulders rippling as they push like pistons. Turcotte doesn’t hold back... Page 109 of 113  109.

dialogues.speaker: BELMONT P-A ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: One mile. One minute 34 and one.

dialogues.speaker: CHIC ANDERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The fastest backstretch duel in the history of horseracing!...

dialogues.speaker: BEYER
